Title: Great Basic Space Heater
Review Content: This is a great, basic space heater. I’ve been using it regularly for several months to heat my large basement bedroom, or my office at work. My office has high ceilings and a large window, so it’s hard to keep a balanced temperature.  It heats both spaces well on the low/medium setting and shuts off at intervals when it reaches the desired temperature.If you pick it up, move it or it gets bumped (just testing), the safety switch on the bottom works instantly and shuts it off. It doesn’t shut off after so many hours, but I knew that going in. This is one of the reasons I did not want a remote—having to go over to the machine to shut it on and off makes me more aware.I wasn’t looking for other bells and whistles so it met my need. I have had no issues and would likely buy another if needed.

The rest of the time, however, it is perfectly fine since you can just adjust it throughout the day while you're awake.

Title: Reliable & Cozy Space Heater – Perfect for Small Rooms!
Review Content: This little heater is a game-changer for cold nights! It’s compact, lightweight, and super easy to move from room to room. I love using it in my living room, especially on hardwood floors, where my feet tend to get cold. It heats up quickly and keeps my space warm and toasty without taking up much room.One of my favorite features is the adjustable heat dial, which gives a wide range of temperature settings rather than just a simple high or low. The ceramic heating element has two intensity levels—high and low—which affect how much heat it emits. This makes it really versatile because you can fine-tune the warmth to your preference rather than being stuck with only preset options.The oscillation feature is another big plus! Instead of just heating one spot, it moves back and forth to spread warmth evenly across the room. It even has a fan-only mode, which is great for air circulation when heat isn’t needed.The only small downside is that it dries out the air, so if I leave it on overnight, I sometimes wake up with a dry throat. But that’s pretty common with space heaters and can be fixed with a humidifier.Overall, it’s a fantastic heater for small rooms, offices, or just warming up your feet while relaxing! The safety features, like tip-over and overheat protection, give me peace of mind, and the build quality feels solid for the price. Definitely worth it!

Title: Heating element clogs relatively quickly, but it also heats up quickly
Review Content: I've had four small electric space heaters, and of these, the heating elements in the Amazon Basics units have the greatest tendency to get clogged with dust due to the higher airflow. But they heat up much more quickly than the others.Although these heaters have temperature sensors which shut them down if they get too hot inside, it's still a good idea to keep their heating elements clean to get the best performance. There might be some trick to cleaning them without opening the heater, such as hitting them with a powerful blast of compressed air from the front. I couldn't find anything about this on the internet. The standard advice is to leave cleaning up to experts, but I've dismantled my heaters many times  to get at the back of their heating elements and vacuum them, and haven't had any serious problems. I tried using a shop vac with a cut-off funnel as a nozzle to pull air backwards through the heater, but this didn't get the heating element clean.It might be sufficient to open the heater up and blast the front of the heating element with canned compressed air, but the only way to know that it's clean is to remove it and examine the back. Removing the element involves prying some plastic pieces outward and prying the element out, all at the same time. Just be careful to avoid touching the front or back of the element with anything hard, because the element is made of soft metal which bends easily, and this can create obstructions to airflow.I'd set the heater on a soft cushion so that it can sink in and remain stable, and to be safe, you should wear safety glasses in case a plastic piece breaks off and goes flying at your eye, although the plastic used for my Amazon Basics units isn't very brittle and doesn't seem like it will break off.Another option (which I've been meaning to try, but haven't gotten around to it) would be to put something like a True Blue electrostatic filter on the back, and vacuum or wash the filter periodically. The advantage of an electrostatic filter is that it contains a permanent ionic charge which traps dust although the filter allows air to pass relatively easily, assuming that it's not too clogged.At first, I had some difficulty reassembling these heaters after vacuuming them, but after opening them and reassembling them a few times, it became easier. I was having difficulty with reassembling one of them, and accidentally dropped it onto a carpet on a wooden floor, and then it was easy to reassemble it, although I can't guarantee that this will help in all cases, and it might damage it instead.

Title: Relief from bitter winter days
Review Content: I bought this for my chilly study, which has only one vent for heating, and on especially cold New England days I need a bit more heat.  This compact heater is very effective.  It has lots of setting options, and is easy to use.  There are no temperature controls, no remote control, but I have no complaints.  Simple is better.  You just turn it on until you feel you're warm enough, then you can turn it down a bit to help maintain the warmth without over-doing it.  It has a light to let you know it is connected and ready to use, and while it is smaller than a lot of space heaters, yet it quickly gets the average size room nice and comfortable in very little time.  I think overall space heaters are becoming smaller and more effective.  It is light weight, easy to carry, and the directions are very clear.  My only complaint is that it is kind of loud.  Nonetheless, it makes a big difference, and I can't imagine getting through the winter without it.

Title: Love it!
Review Content: I had the older version of this little heater that I've kept in my shop under the desk for a couple of years now. The fan finally died on me last week so I decided to stick with the same company/brand since my previous little heater lasted so long and put off just enough heat to get me through (though I did have to drape a little jacket over my lap from time to time).The new and highly improved heater came in this morning and boy oh boy I gotta tell ya, what an improvement it is!! The oscillation option is a game changer! I didn't expect much since the last one's heat was so centralized, but this little guy packs a punch! Not only does it produce more than enough heat with the oscillation off, but once on it distributes heat to an area roughly 3ft wide. I have a rather large desk and it covers the entire underside with heat.I highly recommend this little heater and plan on picking up a second one for my wife as soon as I finish up this review!Happy New Year 2025!

Title: It Works Great!
Review Content: You never know how something is going to work until you get it into your place.  I have an old portable heater which still works, it fills in where I need it.  But the place I moved into a couple years ago, has high ceilings and it takes a lot to heat the rooms.  My kitchen & bathroom, tiny though they are, have tall windows that the wood was never replaced on the outside when they put the new windows in & a lot of air (cold air right now) leaks in around them, so those rooms are freezing.  There is only 1 register for the 2 rooms.  I keep it on 66 degrees Fahrenheit for heat because it's heated with Natural Gas & it's expensive. This new heater works great for the area!  It keeps me toasty with the door closed to my bedroom for those 2 rooms!  I am so grateful to have it!  And it oscillates, sending it's warmth all through those rooms!

Title: Very happy with my purchase
Review Content: I am so glad that my husband showed me this heater.  I kept complaining that I was cold in my home office and I was putting on sweaters to keep me warm.  He wanted me to be comfortable so he did some research and thought that this would be a good solution to my problem.  I was not comfortable using a heater because I thought that they can be dangerous and catch on fire.  After reading all of the reviews, I thought it was worth a try.  It was economically priced and would not take up too much space.  It has a great safety feature that shuts it off if it tips over or is moved at all.  It arrived early the next day and within 2 minutes of putting it on, I felt the warmth of this heater.  I got an oscillating one and I am glad that I did.  You can choose either one but I thought it would be wise to get an oscillating model because I would have the option of using it either way.  If you are looking for a heater that doesn't take up much space and is priced right, this is the one.  You won't be disappointed.

Title: Nice little heater until it stops working after 6-months of use
Review Content: I bought this in late September 2024 because my office at work is always too cold. My office is small, less than 150 sq foot. The heater had good reviews and for the price, a good buy. It worked great until late March 2025. Then it just stopped working. I turned it off, unplugged it and waited an hour before turning it back on again. It briefly came back on (less than a minute) then died again. I use it every day during the work week. I shut it off when I leave the office and that happens frequently. I am disappointed that it wasn't a better product and lasted longer. For the price ($25.00) and an Amazon Basics, I expected it to last longer than 6-months.

Title: Simple and works well but pretty darn loud
Review Content: I rarely give things five stars so this got three because I couldn't give it four, it's just way too loud. I have a tower heater that moves way more air that is way quieter. In fact the tower heater is quieter on high than this Amazon basics heater is on low. I don't know if I got a defective one or if it's just that loud. It's not vibrating or the fan is not rubbing on anything. It's just not well designed for being quiet. I really like the oscillation function. It's just a switch to turn it on or off. And I love that these are not touch sensitive buttons but they're actually physical dials for the fan speed and the temperature setting. That way you can put it on a smart plug to just turn it on or off whenever you want without even getting up. Much better than a smart heater which will probably not work in a few years and probably has an app that's just stealing your data haha! I bought this heater to use in my hobby room so being a little loud is not a huge deal. And it does distribute the heat well. So if you don't mind your heater being a little loud or you're using it in a situation where that doesn't matter much, this would be a good heater especially for the price!

Review Content: For as small as it is, this space heater still works well for at least a nearly 20ftx20ft room. I haven't tried it elsewhere yet. It would be better if it had a remote control so that you could adjust it from a distance, but otherwise was a good deal when I got it on sale.The safety feature works well. If the base of the heater isn't flat against a surface, it does shut off immediately.I noticed that if you switch it to rotating mode, then depending where the power cord is or what it's against, it may cause the unit to be dragged or move a bit across a surface when it turns due to the power cord being pulled with the motion, but once it settles into place it stays, which is fine as long as that's the angle you want it at, or you can turn rotation off.Once it gets the room heated up initially, it gets warm enough for me to need to turn it down to between 50 percent to almost nothing at times, sometimes I even just start in the middle. As with any heater, you may feel a bit of dryness in your mouth/throat/nose if using it to sleep without a humidifier.Edit: A downside I've noticed is that while this is small and convenient since you can place it on a standing surface and not take up floor space, it has created deep scratches on my nightstand. It's either the edges of the plastic on the base of the unit or perhaps the piece (or screw in the center of) that is the safety trigger for when it gets lifted or tipped. Really wish they had put some soft padding or something over those areas to prevent damage to surfaces.

It truly delivers on its promise and provides great value for the price!

Title: Great for small spaces but noisy
Review Content: I bought this ceramic portable heater to warm up my office, and it does the job well. It heats up small spaces quickly and efficiently. However, the downside is that it's a bit on the noisy side, especially if you need quiet. Also, it only blows in one direction, so you might need to adjust it to get the warmth where you want it. Overall, it's a solid option if you're looking for a budget-friendly heater for a small area.

Title: BUY THIS!
Review Content: This was probably the best product I have ever bought off of Amazon. I bought two of these heaters when I came home. My house was at 58°. I waited maybe a half hour to unboxed them and plug them up and within two hours my thermostat has gone up by 20°. I live in an old stick, built house about 950 square feet  the Raleigh area. However, I am a Boston girl through and through. I have always been told in the winter time and I’ve always wearing socks to bed an  layer, a sweatshirt. I really do not like using my “heating” aka propane- yes the type of propane you put in a propane tank grill. This is compact, oscillating, and heats a decent amount of square feet up in a very, very short period of time. I wish I had found this sooner. Overly satisfied and kind of warm!

Title: Not The Best Tip Over Switch Design.
Review Content: Heater is tipsy on uneven floors and carpet because the bottom is smaller than the body. If you gently touch the heater or reposition it just slightly it will rapidly turn off and on sometimes multiple times.I prefer heaters with an internal tip over switch. Those will only turn off only if they actually tip over.Good heater otherwise. 900 watts low. 1500 watts high.

Title: One very well-built Space Heater that will last and last
Review Content: I brought this space heater back in 2013, 12 years later it's still going strong. There's one thing that's not mentioned and that it has an automatic thermostat. when you set the thermostat at a setting, it will turn off and on dependent upon the temperature in the room. The lower the setting, the better it does this. Even in the "off" setting, it will still come on and off if the temperature falls below that setting.  Also, it runs cool and has many safety features the others do not. The plug never runs hot in the wall outlet. So, from that perspective it's safe as well.  You should still never leave it on when you're not present as with all heaters for common safety, it's still the safest, toughest, well-built space heater if seen. When the one I have finally dies in the future, 12 years going strong, I will no doubt by another one for another 12 years!

Title: Perfect for the chill of fall
Review Content: Every morning we wake up in North New Jersey chilled to the bone. Fall has just started but it is a most wicked cold that sets into your bones. My brother-in-law's house heater is broken right now so we just have to grin and bear it. 6 of us live here so we're just a pile of blankets right now until the repairman can get over here. I have little patience for feeling cold, I just downright hate it. Cold has always been worse for me it seems than for others as cold actually feels painful to me. My fingers get stiff, slow and curl a little depending on how cold it is and my thighs tend to burn. If someone can't provide the heat for me I will go solve the problem myself.I researched heaters found on Amazon for 2 or 3 weeks looking at not only star ratings but user reviews. This one looked pretty good to me but to be honest it wasn't the forerunner in my heater quest. The Lasko "My Heat Personal Ceramic Heater" was actually my first choice but after some mixed reviews and some people calling it junk I passed on it. I had it in the cart ready to go I just couldn't reconcile myself to all the reviews that said it stopped working. It's compact size had me eyeing it also over this one but ultimately I chose this ceramic heater and I am very glad I did.This heater is by no means giant but it is bigger than what I would have hoped for. I honestly only wanted something about the size of a coffee mug but that's a little unrealistic and anything that is that small seems to have reviews of it breaking or making strange noises, I liken it to a chihuahua...shakes,sputters and isn't too stable (falls over fairly easy) due to small size (sorry chihuahua lovers). The dimensions of this heater are 8.5 inches tall X 5.5 inches wide X 6 inches across the top. It's not too big as you can see. The heater does a really good job in the morning of warming us up in the short time between waking up and rushing to get ready for work. In about 10 minutes a frosty room is a pleasantly warm room (we use low setting otherwise the room would be boiling hot in that short time span). I keep the heater elevated on a dresser top at the foot of the bed but pointing towards us and I can actually feel the hot air blowing on me from that far away, I love it!The heater has 2 knobs on the top of it. The first knob for adjusting  0 (on,off) , fan (for cold air), 1(low heat) and 2 (high heat output) and the other knob is your heat/temp control, on the bottom of the knob is a power icon. I haven't exactly figured out WHY the first knob has a little power symbol on it it's not like the knob can actually turn to it and shut off so it appears as if the symbol is there just to take up space. Located between the two knobs is a little oval red light. It is always turned on so long as the heater is plugged in, it never shuts off. As I write this I am in bed, in my fuzzy pajamas with the heat blowing on me...I know I should get up and start my day but the envelope of warm goodness around me is too good to give up - this heater is a dangerous thing when I want to stay in bed with it blowing on me lol.We paid 20 bucks for it , I can't complain about that at all. Amazon has other heaters selling for insane amounts that don't have half of the rating this little thing does. I am pleased and happy all around with the purchase. A man that HATES any sort of warmth doesn't mind this thing and actually welcomes it in the morning, that says a lot considering it's been a 4 year battle with my man to get some heat in the colder months. He likes it about 50 to 60 inside the house (when we had our own) and I adore 75 - 80 weather. Quite a difference there in what each of us thinks is comfortable temp. I pick on him and just tell him not everyone was born in Siberia (he literally was born in Siberia). So over all I give this thing a 5 star rating based on the almost week we've had it. Here is a quick review of the good, the bad and the ugly of it all...The Good :-Small-Nice silver color-Amazing job warming us and the room up-No typical heater odors other than the "used for the first time" smell you get when any heating element is warmed for the first time-Great price-Sturdy construction-Easy to understand controls-Can provide you with either warm or cool air-Auto temp gauge to shut off when the room is the desired temp-Overheating protection (although I've never had to test it, it's never overheated on me)Decent length cord (it's not the longest but it is longer than most we've had through the years)-Red light always reminds you it's plugged in-casing stays cool to the touch (but the grill gets hot)-Has a little mini handle (good only for VERY small hands)The bad and ugly:-can't figure out why one of the knobs has a power icon when you can't shut it off so that the red light goes out-would be nice if it had tip over protection (although it's pretty stable but there is no accounting for animals or kids that may knock it over)-The handle is not the best it could slip right out of my fingertips since that is all that really gets in there is the tips of my fingersOverall I am very happy. I am a heater fiend and I just love this thing. I would buy it again if for some reason this thing kicked the bucket.

Title: Great little heater; works much better than expected
Review Content: Got 2 of these for my 2 'coldest' rooms so I can lower the thermostat during the day and use these instead.(I would never use any space heater at night when I am unconscious and not able to keep an eye on them).They are small but powerful with 2 heat settings, a 'fan only' function, and a thermostat dial with 11 settings. It has an automatic 'overheat' kill switch, shutting the appliance off if it begins to overheat (but I've not experienced that to date). While the instructions caution one about the ceramic exterior getting hot, I have not experienced that even though I've been watching (and feeling) for it.  This unit measures 8.5" high, 6" wide and 4.5" in depth (smaller than 2 boxes of tissues stacked upright)and is pleasing to the eye. Easy to use, one can turn it on and set it to run as long as desired, or use the thermostat setting for it to come on/turn off as the area warms to your settings. Easy to set the thermostat function: turn unit on full blast until the room/area warms to your satisfaction, then slowly turn the thermostat dial down until the unit stops running. After that, it will turn on/off as the room cools/warms per your setting. To reset to a different therm. setting, simply let unit cool completely (unplug for about 10 minutes) and you can reset as before. A small, unobtrusive red 'on' light peeks at you from the center front top of the unit so one always knows it is plugged in. They require a 120 outlet and instructions caution NOT to use surge suppresors, power strips or extension cords for its operation.I've used these in the cellar while I'm doing laundry/ironing (unfinished cellar is cold and damp in the winter months), and aside from keeping me from getting chilled, I've noticed it helps to dry the clothes on the cellar lines & drying racks also.It is intended for use on the floor, not on furniture. This may be an issue for those with young children or pets, but it is easily placed behind an open bottomed chair, area table with legs, beneath a coffee table, etc. Right now, one is beneath my kitchen table with the chairs in front of it as the 6 dogs go in/out the back door all day/night long. I no longer have to walk into a freezing kitchen because I've had to open the back door so often. This little powerhouse of a unit kicks on as soon as the cold air hits the floor and runs until the kitchen is warm again and it is only on the 2nd setting! There are 9 higher settings from which to choose. While it isn't completely silent in operation, it isn't loud either. A normal hum similar to a small fan on very low setting. My stove hood fan on "low"  makes more noise than this unit as does a kettle of water almost reaching its boiling point.I like these so much, I'm back for a few more for my sister. Her 3rd floor apartment is in a historically-old multi-family dwelling with poor insulation. She is always cold, always catching colds and her heating bills are astronomical trying to keep the apartment warm. I think she's going to love these as well as I do as she can move them to any room she is in at the time without having to raise the heat in the entire apartment.Can't go wrong with these, esp. this price!Edit: Super Bowl Sunday, 2/7/10 - wanted to see if one of these would warm the entranceway as hubby's guests come in/out during the game today as we leave the beverages outside stuffed in the snow to keep them really, really cold. I didn't use an extension cord, but for the area I wanted to place the heater, I did try a surge suppressor. Several times. I say 'several times' because each time I turned the heater on, the circuit breakers for that entire side of the house triggered. So I thought to myself "Self, maybe it is this particular heater. Try one of the other 2 I have in other rooms..." Ok, so I thought it was a good idea at the time...but it wasn't. Each heater in succession triggered the circuit breakers. I guess the instructions meant what they said. Use this heater only directly connected to the actual outlet! Whew -glad I found this out BEFORE the game! I'd probably be relegated to the back yard and the dog house had I blown the circuit breakers during the game....:)

Title: ARE YOU A WARM AND HAPPY CAMPER?
Review Content: My collection of small space heaters started back in 1986 with a heavy metal Pelonis Classic Ceramic Disc Heater which still works...running at half speed on a cold concrete basement floor 20 feet from the neatest flammable object and surrounded by smoke alarms. This is the only place I feel that it's safe to run it 24x7.A few brands have died in the dust but most have lasted over ten years. I'll explain the reasons for their long lifespan later.For the money, safety, ease of necessary alterations and cleaning, the Lasko 754200 Ceramic Heater is my go-to guy.  Amazon.com touts this heater as their #1 Best Seller.Running several space heaters in a home can sometimes get frustrating if two are set on 1500 watts and happen to be on the same circuit. When the circuit breaker trips, everybody freezes. The same thing happens in conjunction with any 1500 watt appliance like a hair dryer or microwave.The first thing I would suggest is to learn exactly what outlets in your dwelling are on the same breaker.  I've clearly labeled our circuits in the breaker box in black ink.I'm not a heating and air specialist. However, I'm pretty good at knowing when a room is comfortable. I'd rather have two of these heaters running on low (900 watts) watts with thermostats set at 75% on opposite sides of a room than one heater burning 1500 watts in the middle set on high.  It just isn't safe to run any space heater at max unless you stay with in.  Most folks have to walk away every now and then.Now, it's vent time, pun intended.The biggest problem I've had with space heaters over the years is that most do not have filters. Amazon's #1 seller (I currently have 3 in use) does not have a filter. Any dust, lint, hair or whatever that's floating in the air is sucked in from the back. Most of it burns up and turns to ash and is emitted back out into the room for allergy sufferers to breathe and choke on. Some of it collects inside the unit, especially on ceramic disc style heaters.The very first thing I do with these non-filtered space heaters is to add a filter. It's very simple. And the Lasko is the easiest of any I've done.  The contoured box shape is conducive for this addition and makes the filter less visible.Attach strips of adhesive (male) Velcro to the back of the frame around the air intake. Carbon-treated filter material is widely available. I use so much of it that I buy it buy the bulk roll. This stuff adheres to male Velcro just like female Velcro.I cut a section of carbon pre-filter that fits and stick it on. Granted, it's not the most attractive thing in the world but it works. Every couple of days, I lightly run a vacuum hose over the filter. Do not try this with a roller brush. GLUP! Your filter is gone.Every month, I replace the filter. Just peel off the old and stick on the new. Every space heater in our home serves a dual purpose of both heater and air filter.Most of my space heaters are over ten years old and run as good as new.Charred debris and pollution building up inside space heaters is the number one cause of failure and fires, especially if they are run on high, causing the cost of operation to soar and the efficiency to plummet.If you have an old ceramic heater that's seems to be getting weak, "carefully" blow it out with a low-pressure air hose or a can of compressed air in the sunlight. You'll be shocked at the dust that comes out. If you try this with a high-pressure air hose, you might need to go shopping for a new heater.Warm air is nice in winter. Clean warm air is a luxury.One more beef, sidebar or addendum:I've never owned a space heater with an accurate thermostat. Not one.  The coldest air in the house is on the floor.  If the heater is on the floor, so is the thermostat.For what it's worth...and that would be $38.00...the LUX WIN 100 plug-in thermostat works great.I know, the heater only cost $25.00.Since most wall outlets are near floor level, I had to use a short  extension cord with a flat wall plug to elevate the thermostat to the desired level but that was not a problem.I'm currently experimenting with one sitting on a table (mid-body height) running a Lasko 754200 space heater set on medium.  After two weeks, I'm very impressed with the results.There are large furniture-style space heaters that cost over $200.00.Some reviewers claim that the thermostats work. Some disagree.My combination for $63.00 is working fine and I'm a warm and happy camper.  I can't believe I just said that.

Title: Very pleased

Title: Five years of prolonged use and it’s still amazing
Review Content: I bought this heater in 2020 I believe. It is still kicking and I have legit used it 4 hours a day, five days a week since purchased. It provides lots of heat and is low on the noise. I’m only having issues with it now because of how much dust is caked up behind the coils and it’s really hard to clean. $30 for five years? I’d 10000% buy another.

Title: No complaints after almost 10 years
Review Content: My Amazon history shows I've had two of these space heaters for almost 10 years.My office building is always very cold, even in the summertime, and I've run one of these for nearly 9 hours a day about 4 days a week in my office.  Quick math shows it has easily over 15,000 hours of use and it's still working perfectly fine.  My second one has run for more than 3 hours every evening in the fall and winter to take the chill out of my home office, and has been just as reliable.  It probably has "only" about 5,000 hours on it.  I only run them on the 750W setting to avoid tripping any circuit breakers.No complaints here at all.  Even if they die tomorrow, I'll have gotten more than my expected value out of them over the years and I'll look for another Lasko to replace them.EDIT 3/31/2025The power knob on the unit with less use broke just a few months after writing this review.  The heater still works fine and can be controlled with pliers.  I only use it in the #1 setting, so I got a $3 plug-in outlet switch to turn it on and off instead.  Still going strong!

Title: It's hot!
Review Content: Produces adjustable temperature heat very quickly.  Nice small size. Have bought several for staff who get cold in the office and everyone who gets one loves it.  This version has a very stiff cord that hasn't relaxed  over weeks of use.  And it's pretty loud.

Title: Very glad we bought it at the time
Review Content: I wasn't really sure what to expect with this little heater.We have an upstairs bedroom in a rental place (where we can't do major changes), and itis very chilly in the winter. Add wind, and it gets freaky cold inside! We've actually hadice on the closet walls before.So, I wanted to get a small space heater that wouldn't require us running the central heatif only our bedroom was cold.This little guy does the job very well.I don't find the noise annoying - it is like a computer running, with slight magnification.It is not as noisy as a fan. I don't mind it a bit, and it can be like white noise, blockingout other small annoyances.This is so completely adjustable, it makes it great.I've used both the high and low power settings, and don't see a huge difference between them.I guess the high technically heats up faster, but again, I didn't really notice.The other dial is how warm you want the air to be that comes out.I've used it on many of the settings so far. Yesterday, for example, had 30-40 mph winds hereand it was very cold in the bedroom - cold enough I had a hard time sewing something by hand!I put the little heater aimed at my desk, and within 1/2 hr, the room was very comfortable.The room is about 12' x 10'.  By the time my daughter got home from school, it was too hot,and we had to turn it off for a while!All in all, I'm very happy with it. We bought two different kinds, one for downstairs and onefor upstairs, to try to cut back on our utility bill. The other brand works just fine too, butI think this one is a little better! : )All in all, I would definitely recommend it. It won't heat a 2-story house, but it does 2 or 3 roomsto a pleasant temperature (I don't like it super hot anyway, but it gets to 72 pretty easily) very well.Upstairs, we have two bedrooms and a small bathroom. I can put this in the hallway, and, although ittakes a little longer, will have the upstairs comfortably warm in an hour or so. The bedroom alonewith the heater in the room takes much less time. I've even had it near the desk when my handswere freezing while typing!Not sure how great the fan alone will be - I'll try that when it gets stuffy some day.But I bought it for heating, and it does exactly what it says, and does it well.Very pleased with the purchase.=============================================================UPDATE:Well, we had our first problem with the heater today!We have used it probably ten times this winter, and it has done a wonderful job of warmingthe bedroom/hall area. HOWEVER - today, March 29, we went to unplug the heater and box itback up for next winter's use. This is where the problem began!I tried to unplug the heater, and couldn't do it! I tried and failed, tried the other hand and failed.When my son got home, had HIM try and he failed!  It took the two of us to get the heater disconnectedfrom the plug, and when we finally did, the prongs came out of the plug!! OMG.Well, THAT was an interesting development!I checked on the website, and the heater has a one-year warranty on parts. So, I contactedLasko via their customer care center, and we'll see what they will do about it!I could hardly believe it! We've had it plugged in since December, so around three months,but I really don't think that's long enough to create a stuck plug problem!I'll update about how Lasko customer service is once I hear back, and we find a resolution to the problem.Until then - unplug carefully! You can see the glue on the end of the plug on ours!UPDATE:No response from Lasko yet, so it is looking like I'll be buying another brandof small space heater for next winter. What a shame. I really did like this one.My husband has another brand, however, that did equally well at heating the room.Lasko isn't the only player in the game at this point. Disappointing on the customer serviceoversight. I've had it too long to ask Amazon to handle the problem - it isn't their faultthe plug was faulty - but sure wish I could send it back for a replacement!I am dinging it one star both because of the plug, and because of the lack of support overa product that was only a few months old and allegedly still under warranty.UPDATE OCT 2013:Here it is, late 2013, and Lasko never bothered to respond to our concerns.The heater has been sitting in the hallway since the plug pulled out several months ago.Now that winter is getting closer again, I am back on Amazon, looking for another heater.It will NOT be this one - it worked like a champ, UNTIL we needed to unplug it!Note that it is STILL UNDER WARRANTY, and they won't respond to the problem.What the worst part was was Lasko ignoring our request entirely. No replacement heater,replacement cord, credit towards another one, nothing at all.So, we will be looking at other brands. Most have similar wattages now, so there is noreason to be brand loyal, when they didn't care a bit about us.

Title: Love this heater!
Review Content: I bought one of these heaters to use downstairs in my computer room. That room has no heat at all in it. I spend a lot of time on my computer and in the winter I just about freeze to death down there. I did research here on Amazon and read many reviews before deciding on this one. I really liked the idea that it was thermostat controlled. I put the heater next to my computer desk on the floor and set it to #1 and then turned up the other knob until the heat started running. This heater put out a lot of heat, even on the 1 setting, and my feet began to feel hot. So I got a small step stool I had and put it on that to see if the heat would cover the rest of my body better. This was a big improvement because then my whole body was warm. In fact, it warmed me so well that I had to push the heater further away from me and not point it directly on me because it did get a little too warm after awhile. My computer room is a rather large room, at least 16X24, so the room does not get toasty warm with this heater. But it does take off the chill of the room and makes it comfortable.I have never had to use the #2 setting on this heater and from what I understand from reading here, the lower the number that you use, the less electricity that you use.I liked this heater so well I decided to buy another one for a large bathroom that we have--the bathroom is as big as a very small bedroom. I take showers and this bathroom is the only one that has a shower stall in it, but during the winter it feels so cold in there after you get out of the shower. So I ordered another one. Evidently the second heater I ordered did not come from the same seller and later I found out it was a refurbished heater. That would explain why this 2nd heater did not run well. Not only did it not push out the heat, it made a terrible noise. I told my husband that something was wrong with the heater and had him to compare the 2 heaters side by side and even he could tell the difference in how much the heaters put out. I call Amazon and told them the problem. I sent it back to Amazon, free shipping back, and re-ordered another one of these heaters. It was when I decided to send the 2nd heater back that I discovered it was a refurbished heater--and the price for the refurbished heater was a higher price than the  band new heat I bought the first time. There was only about 3 months difference between the times I ordered the first and the second heater so there should not have been that much of a rise in price.The 3rd heater I ordered came and ran just as well as the first one did--and was a cheaper price than the refurbished non working heater I bought the second time. So make sure when you order one of these heaters that you are not ordering a used/refurbished heater or you might run into the same problem I had.Would I order another one of these heaters again? You bet, because for the money they put out a lot of heat and work very well.

I really liked the idea that it was thermostat controlled. I put the heater next to my computer desk on the floor and set it to #1 and then turned up the other knob until the heat started running. This heater put out a lot of heat, even on the 1 setting, and my feet began to feel hot. Title: Super small heater
Review Content: I didn't realize this heater was quite so tiny. It doesn't heat up my living room in my small apartment, but it would probably be a great heater for a small bathroom.
Manually Corrected Review Content: I didn't realize this heater was quite so tiny. It doesn't heat up my living room in my small apartment, but it would probably be a great heater for a small bathroom.

Title: Absolutely fantastic
Review Content: I've purchased this same model twice, not because the first one broke but because I had a second cold room. These are by far the best space heaters I've ever owned. It's lightweight and tiny, so I was shocked to feel how effective it is. I first used it in a bedroom where the door doesn't shut and there is a gap in the window, and it still warms the space effectively. I run it all night on cold winter nights, and haven't had any safety concerns. Do follow the instructions about plugging it into the wall or a metal power strip, though. I melted a plastic power strip.

Review Content: Simply the best little heater AND fan.  I use the heater periodically and the output is perfect.  I use the fan component every night and it's the right amount of white noise and produces a gentle breeze of air in the room.  Love it!

Title: Great little heater but...
Review Content: This is a great little heater, hence why I have purchased four of them. Great heat output! Only problem I have found with them is the heat selection knob is prone to break (two of my four have). My recommendation is that if you receive one that the selection knob seems to hard to turn,, return it for another, because it will break pretty quickly.

Title: It does what I need it for (warming my face while sitting outside), but BEWARE...
Review Content: You get what you pay for I guess, but all in all, I like what I paid for, and you can't really go too wrong for the price.  I bought it with one purpose in mind ...to set it on a table on the back patio when I sit out back in the freezing weather.  I tend to like to breathe in really cool fresh air, but I don't necessarily like to feel that cold while doing so.Wearing thick socks, heavy coat, and winter cap, I'll sit out on the back patio in a lawn chair during the late fall and winter to enjoy my cold air, and at this time of the year in a northern state, I don't have to worry about inhaling bugs, or things crawling on me.  It's wonderful.  Many a time I'll be out there with a blanket or two over me, as well as under me.  My head still gets pretty cold though, to the point where I have resorted to pulling the blanket up over my head at times.With this little heater sitting next to me on a table within 3 feet, I no longer need to do that.  It warms the side of my face just fine, which in turn warms the rest of me up fairly well.  Even in 15 degree weather, I can feel toasty and snug as a bug in a rug, enjoying the cool, soothing outdoor air.  Then, I turn it off & on when needed.  If a strong breeze is blowing, it may not be quite as effective.  If you want to try something similar, be sure to set up right next to the house by an outside outlet.  DO NOT use an extension cord!Now...  As for the "BEWARE" part...  First thing I did out of the box was place it on the smooth kitchen table to test it.  Once turned on, I noticed it had a very slight vibration to it, just enough to make the unit move ever so slowly (as other reviewers have reported).  If yours does this, you may not want to leave it alone, or else place the unit on a not so smooth surface.  You certainly don't want the thing falling off the table unattended, or inching it's way over towards something flammable on the floor.  One thing I intend to do is buy four stick-on rubber feet, which I will adhere to the bottom of unit.  Hopefully, this will stop it from slowly sliding around on smooth surfaces.The only other gripe I have is that I think the handle could have been designed much better.  You should really use both hands when carrying, because it almost slides off your fingertips when carrying by handle.  Otherwise, I love it.

Title: Effective, compact heater that met my expectations for function and value.
Review Content: I have a 14'x14' corner office with a lot of window exposure. In the winter, it gets cold while the rest of the office is comfortable. I bought this to heat up the office and as a public display of disdain of our office buildings HVAC people.Pros:- Effective heat. As noted, it heats my 14'x14' corner office to the point that my feet sweat which is my sign to turn it off. Yes, I'm that office sweaty foot guy.- Compact. It sits on my desk. I wouldn't call it stylish and I'm certainly not making it the centerpiece of my desk, but it looks right at home with the other things on my desk.- Value. This looked like the best option in the $25 price range. No regrets.Cons:- Noise. The fan is a little bit on the loud side and it's not adjustable so far as I can tell. Keep in mind that I'm a typical guy - I did not read the small instruction booklet so I could be wrong about its one-speed-fits-all approach, but if the trade off is frozen fingers I'll deal with it. It's not loud enough that it's going to impede a conversation, but it is loud enough that I turn it off when someone comes into my office. To be fair the level of noise seems appropriate given the fan size, but I'm not an expert on fans so don't quote me on that.- Smell. For the first several days of use, it gives off that funny "new heating appliance smell" that's almost like chemical burning. I can't describe it any other way except that my new toaster had the same problem. Given my toaster is touching food and this thing isn't, I'm not too concerned, but it's not pleasant. After a week of consistent use, the smell is still present, but very muted compared to when it was brand new. I have to try and notice it to notice it at this point.- Thermostat efficacy. The thermostat works. I do find that the same setting gives me different levels of heat based on environmental temperatures, but hey, at $25 I'm not expecting a WiFi-enabled smart heater that can carry payloads to the International Space Station.- Vibration. The narrow rails on the bottom of the device that contact the surface of whatever it's resting on are not soft. When the unit is on it vibrates and this is noticeable on a hard surface. Easily solved with something soft (I used folded paper) underneath it. The folded paper I put under it isn't visible, so no aesthetic issues. Your boss would probably not approve if you put this unit on top of your inbox papers. Just saying.

Title: does the job!

Title: Good little heater for small spaces
Review Content: I recently purchased this heater for use in my office after researching many others on Amazon.  So far, it's worked pretty well, and I would recommend it as an inexpensive solution for small spaces. I'd give it more like 3.5 stars if I could, given that it's only good in certain situations.  Here are some pros and cons:Pros:- Heats up quickly, pretty much as soon as you turn it on.- Temperature gauge setting allows you to adjust level of heat.- Cord is several feet long and allows for easy placement.- Shallow grip on the back makes it easy to move.- It's compact and easy to store.Cons:- It doesn't produce a whole lot of heat, even on the highest setting, so it's best to keep it close to you and for use in very small spaces. (I keep it under my desk pointed at my legs in my drafty office and it does the trick).- It isn't noisy, but it does produce a little bit of sound.  Nothing you can't tune out easily in an office setting, but if you're using it in the bedroom for sleeping, it might be a little distracting if you're a light sleeper. It's about the level of white noise you'd expect for a small space heater, so nothing to worry about.- Not sure if it has a safety setting if it gets knocked over (my old one automatically shut off if it went on its side.  This one doesn't appear to have auto shut-off).  This might be a deal-breaker for you if you have small kids or pets.- Doesn't seem to be much of a difference in fan speed/strength between the "1" and "2" setting.Other Notes:- Don't plug this into a power strip -- it will max it out.  Make sure you plug directly into a wall outlet.- It seems to be made of decent quality hard plastic.- The other reviewers mentioned a plastic smell upon the first few days of operation, which concerned me a little.  It was only slightly noticeable to me, and not as big of a deal as I thought.  It got better after using it a couple times.  It still occasionally comes back for the first few minutes of operation, but it's not too bothersome.  I'm hoping it will "burn off" completely as I keep using it.- Overall, it's a decent little space heater for the money, but don't expect it to warm up the whole room.  It's best used relatively near one person.

Title: Nice little office heater
Review Content: I bought this heater because I was sick to death of complaining that I was cold at work and always sitting with a blanket over my lap or never taking my jacket off.  Now it sits under my desk about two feet from my legs and keeps me toasty warm while the so-called "heating system" in my office blows cold air on me.  I was looking for something a tiny bit quieter but the noise is acceptable - it has a sound level of a small clip fan, one of the ones that are about 8" in diameter, on the low setting and, after all, it is a fan of sorts so a certain noise-level is a given.  It is also a little quieter due to the fact that it's underneath my desk, not sitting on top of it.  Also, I've noticed that the noise kind of cuts the buzz of the lights in my office which is pretty irritating.The controls are easy to read and clear to use.  The "power" on the left has four settings: Off, fan (w/ no heat), low heat and high heat.  The temperature setting doesn't actually control the temperature of the air that's coming out of the unit, that is a constant.  What it does is sets the thermostat inside the unit to reach a certain temperature, say 70 degrees, and then turn the unit off.  When it gets colder than 70 degrees the unit clicks back on, returns the space to that temperature and then turns off again similar to the way your home's HVAC system turns on and off to maintain temperature in your home.  If the turning on and off bugs you, just keep the thermostat on the highest setting and it should run constantly.The face of the unit gets a little bit warm to the touch after it turns off but not so badly that it burns me to touch it immediately after (though I have my thermostat set to less than half-way to the hottest setting, like a third of the way or around there).  I tend to kick my shoes off when I'm sitting and if my feet get a little chilly I just hold them in front of the heater or about 10 seconds and I'm good to go again.Overall, a nice product.  Does what I want it to do, does it with a little more noise than I expected but it is acceptable and I no longer have to wear a hat, gloves, scarf and thick socks to work every day. =^)

Title: Perfect Little Heater!
Review Content: If you're someone like me who can't stand to be too hot, or too cold, this is the ideal heater for you. This nifty little heater packs quite a bunch, despite it's size and cost. It's user friendly, and all it takes (to go from hot to cold / or vice versa) is a turn of dial. It's small, compact, easy to carry (due to it's built in handle), and the cord can extend pretty far too!: Pro's :- Very simple interface - extremely user friendly. It has two dials. (Zero [Off], Fan, 1 [Heat], & 2 [Heat] // Second dial is the temperature control), how much easier can it get?- Ideal for small rooms (dorm rooms, bedrooms, bathrooms, offices, etc...)- Easy to move (has built in handle).- Light weight.- Cute design (has a very modern-esk appeal to it. It's not fancy, but it's not terribly plain either).- Has adjustable thermostat that goes from light heat/cool to VERY HOT heat/cool.- Minimal amount of noise (won't bother those who aren't light sleepers).- Durable. (I don't recommend throwing it around, but it has been dropped twice and I've had no problems)- Power down is quick and painless. Takes a few minutes to go from hot to "this thing was on?" cold.: Con's :- Heater has to be placed fairly close to you in order for the cold/heat to actually reach you. Depending on your hot/cold preferences, the normal/recommended length away from your body should be between a two to six feet. IF, on the heat setting, the heater is placed closer to user than two feet, it will be extremely uncomfortable and will most likely burn user(s) skin if left stationary.- For light sleepers/those who need silence while sleeping - this is a terrible product for you. The heater isn't loud, but it isn't quiet either.- Can get TOO hot. Over time, even the lowest of settings (heating only option) can get a little uncomfortable. You may have to adjust it periodically.- Between setting ONE and TWO (as listed on first dial), there is no noticeable differences between those two heat settings.: DO NOT :- DO NOT Place near/point directly at (and leave unattended) fabric furniture. Direct heat + fabric = not good!- DO NOT Place on a wood/glossy desk. Lasko Heater will move about due to vibrations and will most likely fall off if left unattended.: DO :- Keep the fan opening clean/dust free. Extremely quick and painless task and it can be done with a VERY damp wash cloth or paper towel. Turn off and unplug heater before cleaning fan.- Keep away from small children/babies. Heater can get too hot, and can be harmful to young children if the face of heater is touched.---Overall, I'd give this heater a 9/10. : D

Title: LASKO 754200 VS HOLMES HFH111T
Review Content: I needed a couple of new inexpensive space heaters so I decided to do a bake off between this LASKO 754200 and the HOLMES HFH111T.Both have a single fan speed, and a choice of fan only, low heat, and high heat.Both have a thermostat which will turn the unit off once the desired temperature is reached.Both have internal over temperature protection which needs to be reset by unplugging the device and letting things cool down.LASKO PLUSThe light is lit if the unit is plugged in so you know if it's plugged in by a look only.  I want to leave space heaters unplugged when I'm not around and this makes it easy to tell.Quieter than HOLMES:  ~55DB vs the HOLMES 60DBSeems more efficient at heating a given volume of air.  Passing my hand in front of either unit at about 18 inches away with heat on high, my hand got rather hot with the LASKO which seemed to have good even hot air distribution over an arc +/-20 degrees of center, but the HOLMES air distribution seemed uneven with more air going to one side, and my hand never got uncomfortable.HOLMES PLUSSimpler packaging:  no internal packaging....  LASKO had: 2 pieces of pressed formed cardboard, plastic wrapping and tape to recycle.The light is lit once the switch is no longer in the OFF position, even if the thermostat has caused the fan to turn off.  Thus you can look at the light to know that the heater *may* be on.  With the LASKO you need to look at the switch to make sure it's going to stay off.More sensitive thermostat.  It takes only a 5 or 10 degree rotation to get the thermostat to go on or off, while the LASKO took about 30 degrees.May very well move more air for the noise.Tip over protection. It has a weight on a switch.  If the unit leaves vertical by more then 60 degrees tipping front or back, the unit will shut off.BOTTOM LINEIf no kids or cats I'd recommend LASKO.  If tip over is a concern, the the HOLMES is an acceptable low cost solution.The LASKO will go in my office where I will appreciate the quiet and the more direct heat, and the HOMES will in the bathroom where the noise and uneven direct heating is less of an issue.

Title: Lightweight and quiet
Review Content: Nice little heater. Only like a foot tall. Pretty quiet just a small hum. One of the bedrooms is a bit chilly so we use this on the cold nights lightweight too.
Manually Corrected Review Content: Nice little heater. Only like a foot tall. Pretty quiet just a small hum. One of the bedrooms is a bit chilly so we use this on the cold nights lightweight too.

Title: Sleek functional fan
Review Content: Just perfect. Needed this small heater for my larger bathroom, helps the cold floor and is so nice after getting out of the shower. Nice thermostat controls, sleek design. Would buy again.
Manually Corrected Review Content: Just perfect. Needed this small heater for my larger bathroom, helps the cold floor and is so nice after getting out of the shower. Nice thermostat controls, sleek design. Would buy again.

Title: Nice and toasty!
Review Content: UPDATE:Three and a half years later, this little heater is still working just as well as it did when I first got it, and it's kept me warm through 4 very cold winters (if you're from the northeast, you know what I mean). I would still very much recommend this heater, but want to add one tip: if you plan to have this heater very close to you (like a work space), make sure you face it towards you, but not directly. The hot air blowing from it tends to dry out my eyes and give me slight headaches at times, which is to be expected. Stay warm, fellow Amazonians!There is a never-ending battle between me and my boss when it comes to the temperature at the office.He likes it to feel like we work at the North Pole, whereas I like to actually feel my extremities. Problematic, see?In comes this cute little heater. I keep it under my desk and have it slightly propped up in front, so that it's facing upwards at about a 45 degree angle. Not only does it keep me nice and toasty throughout the day, but it also helps me to control the temperature around me whenever I need to.The two switches on top of the heater work like so:** Left switch -0: OffFan: No heat, just a fan1: Light heat2: Strong heat** Right switch -13 strength levels (including the - and +), which controls how hot you want the heater to be. This also controls what seems to be the climate control, because the heater periodically shuts off to keep it at that level of heat/temperature.*** SAFETY PRECAUTION: For those of you worried about the metal at the front of the heater getting too hot to the touch, I can attest to the fact that it has never been too hot to touch, thus far. BUT if you have small children around, you might want to keep it elevated or at least blocked off, because the heat itself can get extremely high, and feel like it is burning your skin right off, if you have it on high enough.Otherwise, enjoy and stay warm, my friends!If my review has helped you in any way, please let me know, or hit "Yes" under this review. Thank you! :)

Title: Good little space heater
Review Content: Bought this to help keep the living room warm and cut down on the heating oil use.There are two circular controls, one for the fan and one for the heat. The fan settings are off, fan only and heat settings 1 & 2. That one clicks into position and sounds solid. The heat level control spins easily to adjust how much heat you want. The case itself is cheap plastic that doesn't feel very sturdy. Seems like it would crack open if dropped from a moderate height. The cord is a good length. Ours is about 3' from the wall and there is still some slack.The fan makes some noise but a whole lot less than the fan we use in the summer. Exterior gets a little warm but not too hot to touch. The room gets a  bit of a chill on the lower fan and temp settings but nothing that a sweater can't help with. The high settings do the trick. A slightly larger unit would work better but this was pretty cheap and its small enough to tuck away when not using it. Only had it for a week now so longevity is still a question.Specs says its good for 300 sq ft. which should be enough for the living room. The house is only around 950 sq ft. Only concern I had was the kitchen is right off the living room and there is a hallway for the bedrooms (doors closed) upstairs from the living room. I wasn't sure if it would be strong enough with all that open space.Set this heater and fan on high. Kept the living room quite comfortable as well as the kitchen. The upstairs hallway got so warm, was able to open the bedroom door and take the chill off the air in there as well. Thermostat upstairs reads in the low 70's. The two downstairs rooms are close to meat lockers but we don't use them at night. Overall, so far so good.Just waiting on the electric bill to see which is more expensive, the heating oil or the electricity usage.

Title: A safe room heater with a remote!
Review Content: Excellent small heater.  This heater solves the problem of a drafty room.  I turn it on and my room is comfortable all day. The remote control is very user-friendly.  It is quiet, effective and the safety switch makes me confident that it is safe if it would ever get bumped.

Title: So reliable!
Review Content: What a great little heater. I bought this last year for the few cold days in Mississippi. This year we had snow on the gulf coast and below freezing temperatures. I’ve been using it for more than 12 hours a day to heat the living room of my small apartment and it has been very reliable. So glad I chose this brand - and I hope we never have snow again!

Title: Simple and reliable with basic but effective control of heat level and temperature.
Review Content: We have been using an earlier version of this heater for several years now and it has been very reliable and effective. The early version is now in our insulated lawn building keeping the temperature between 40` and 52` with good regularity. Not that I would recommend this as an application but it is working for us just fine.  The new one is now keeping a bathroom warm for taking showers.

Title: I like it... but shows some signs of damage after a few nights of use.
Review Content: This heater is great at heating up my bedroom. I have inconsistent heating where I live, and therefore turn the Lasko on at nights that are very cold. I am someone who hates getting up in the morning to a freezing chill the moment you lift the covers.So far, it can raise the temperature in my room from 68 F to about 80 F (and probably get higher if I didn't get too hot) in about an hour in my small to medium sized room on the higher settings. On the lower settings it keeps the room at about 76 F and can be adjusted accordingly.I loved this heater, until one day when I looked at the side of the heater, I see it melted itself (see attached pictures) a little. This has not impacted functionality but I had only used the heater for about 4-6 nights over 3 weeks, on the 4th - 6th lowest setting and maybe one night (the first night) on the highest setting. The melted side has made me concerned about the build quality of the particular product I received as only one side has been affected and not the other. Luckily I had contacted the seller and they agreed to refund me the price without returning the product.I do really like my Lasko heater and it works wonderful for its price. I feel that maybe I just happened to have bad luck and got a bad one, so I would definitely pick up another one if this one kicks the bucket.

Title: Good little heater; definitely worth purchasing
Review Content: We had that cold snap a week or so ago, and with temps outside below freezing, there was a definite chill in the air even with our central heat on.  This little heater is amazing and quickly warms up the bathroom (or whatever room you put it in).  I didn't notice a "burning" smell after the first few minutes of use, so I'm not sure why it lingers for some reviewers who've experienced it.The features are great on this little heater. It does not turn off if tipped over, so if you have cats (as we do) who love to play with new things, keep an eye on it and them.  One of my cats tried to perch on it when I first put it down to test it out, and she toppled it in seconds.  They've not bothered with it since the novelty wore off, though.Otherwise, it has dials that you twist to turn it on two speeds and to various levels of warmth.  Once you achieve the warmth level you want in a room, be sure to turn the control to shut off at that warmth level and to cycle back on when the temperature falls below that level; otherwise, you'll soon be blasted out of the room with all the heat it generates.The standard warnings apply: plug it directly into the wall, don't leave it unattended, turn it off AND unplug it when not in use, and keep it at least three or so feet from anything else (this isn't possible in our little bathroom, but we move it to the center of the room and plug it in/turn it on to warm the room up a few minutes before jumping in the shower; when finished, we turn it off, unplug it, and move it back out of the way.).Anyway, it's a great little heater and definitely does its job.  We haven't had it in use for more than a couple of hours at a time, so we have not experienced the plug heating up in the socket as other reviewers have mentioned.  If that happened, though, we would be leery about using it at all.[Edit 10/02/23: I paid $20 for this heater, and it worth that. This review is based on that price point. I would never ever pay twice that for a freaking space heater. If this edit doesn't make the cut, I'm taking stars to reflect my opinion that this heater is not worth more that $20-25.

Title: very good for mild winter weather!
Review Content: Short Review:This heater heats up fast and it very effective.  It can make a small area very warm in just below freezing weather.  Don't forget to turn it off when you leave the room or you risk of blowing out your extension cord or outlet, which could lead to a serious fire hazard.Detailed review:My husband and I bought this help heat up the entertaining area of our garage during the winter. It is about a 12x12 area that has a couch, 3 chairs, and a coffee table.In Texas, it can get below freezing for a few weeks at a time during winter, and we just aren't use to that. When we have friends over, we typically entertain them in the garage so we can talk and laugh without waking up the kids, or smoke without stinking up the house.  We had a $50 heater that we used in the garage, but we found that it was hard to huddle 4-5 adults directly in front of the tiny little heater without feeling like you were having an extremely awkward group hug.We bought this heater to compliment the first heater, hoping they would work together to heat the garage and restore our personal space we so missed. The first time we used it, it heated up within 30 seconds and the whole couch that it was pointed at.  Within a couple minutes we needed to turn it down it was getting so hot. We ended up putting it at the front of our garage and it was able to heat the whole area by itself.The only downfall to this heater is that it doesn't have an automatic shutoff. We accidentally left it on one morning before going to work and it burned up the extension cord we were using with it.  However, that can't really deduct points from the review since pretty much everyone knows they need to unplug a space heater when you are not in the room, but in case you don't, now you do. I would chalk that up to an operator error. We were really lucky it was just out extension cord and not our whole garage that burned up.

Title: So if you have the same issues I definitely recommend this space heater
Review Content: For the last two years that I lived in my shared apartment I would get really cold in the winter in my room. I adjusted my programmable thermostat to be 70 or 72 degrees when I'm home but that wasn't enough sometimes because what it said the temperature was was below what it actually was, and it would heat the whole downstairs floor but I'd spend most of my time in my room. I'd find myself being careful about wearing layers indoors and still being cold and wearing double socks sometimes, and I had sewn two blankets together to be warm when sleeping. But after buying this space heater I didn't have to deal with any of these problems. I was free to just wear one sweatshirt and sleep with one blanket and not wake up freezing. The winter isn't miserable and confusing anymore and I can finally just go about my life normally! So if you have the same issues I definitely recommend this space heater.This space heater heats up my medium size bedroom really well. It does have a thermostat so it will stop working after it has heated the space sufficiently and then start working again when it needs to. I saw someone on a review complain about how it was too hot with any setting, but I don't have that problem. I keep it on the lowest of the two settings on the left dial and somewhere on the lower half of the right dial (in different places depending on how cold it is outside) and it's fine for me. I think the second setting on the left dial is for large rooms. This space heater doesn't have that automatically turn off option if it falls over (which I don't think space heaters of this price ever do), but it seems very balanced on its base, not like it would fall over. Even if it did, the front of it doesn't get so hot that it should cause a fire or anything. This space heater looks like it's very well made in general too. I had a cheaper space heater before that somehow broke and the coils started burning bright red after a while. I don't think that should happen with this space heater because it looks to be good quality. I turn it off when going out for long periods of time to save on energy bills but when I come back I just turn it back on and the room heats up quickly. I love this space heater and I recommend it. :)

Title: nice little portable fan,  lightweight, easy to move around.
Review Content: Ok i just got it today.  It ships in a generic brown box, and taped up.  So i thought it might be a refurb,  it actually could be, but it doesn't look like one after i pulled it out, the plastic and everything looked new.  I turned it on and am testing it now for a few hours as it gets cold at night now.  The fan noise is noticeable, but it's not loud like people say,  like i have it in my room with the tv on and it doesn't bother me.  So far i have it set to middle temp and to fan speed 1,  guess i never hit the temp yet as it hasn't turned off at all yet.  it's been going at the same rate for over an hour.  I do feel the heat though, and for a small unit  8" tall, 6" wide and maybe 6" deep (estimated size),  its not bad.  And some people said it rattled, no rattles at all, fan sounds sturdy and smooth,  smell not really noticeable, at first you do get a slight plasticky smell, but it seemed to fade for me pretty quickly within an hour.  Seems to work well, bought it for work for under my desk as they crank the air every day even on cold days, so looking forward to using it there.  Will post updates if it starts to break down anytime soon, but for now 4 stars,  and if it's durable will up it to 5.  Oh and maybe it's just lasko, but this unit doesn't have a tip over sensor either, lasko seems to use a thermal sensor, that detects unsafe temperatures then shuts down,  which then has to be unplugged and knobs set to off for the unit to reset.  The whole outside was safe to touch after turning off after 4 hours of use.  It's 1500 Watts, so it can eat electricity if used too often.

So i thought it might be a refurb,  it actually could be, but it doesn't look like one after i pulled it out, the plastic and everything looked new.  I turned it on and am testing it now for a few hours as it gets cold at night now.  The fan noise is noticeable, but it's not loud like people say,  like i have it in my room with the tv on and it doesn't bother me.  So far i have it set to middle temp and to fan speed 1,  guess i never hit the temp yet as it hasn't turned off at all yet.  it's been going at the same rate for over an hour.  I do feel the heat though, and for a small unit  8" tall, 6" wide and maybe 6" deep (estimated size),  its not bad.  And some people said it rattled, no rattles at all, fan sounds sturdy and smooth,  smell not really noticeable, at first you do get a slight plasticky smell, but it seemed to fade for me pretty quickly within an hour.  Seems to work well, bought it for work for under my desk as they crank the air every day even on cold days, so looking forward to using it there.  Will post updates if it starts to break down anytime soon, but for now 4 stars,  and if it's durable will up it to 5.  Oh and maybe it's just lasko, but this unit doesn't have a tip over sensor either, lasko seems to use a thermal sensor, that detects unsafe temperatures then shuts down,  which then has to be unplugged and knobs set to off for the unit to reset.  The whole outside was safe to touch after turning off after 4 hours of use.  It's 1500 Watts, so it can eat electricity if used too often.

Title: Our favorite heater - lots of heat for a small device
Review Content: Our old bungalow has some cold spots in the winter - our bathroom, my husband's office, and our bedroom. This heater is small but mighty. During cold weather we run it 24/7 in the bathroom to keep pipes from freezing and to keep it toasty when taking a shower or bath. The price is right, too. Hope they make them forever. I wasn't surprised to find out I have bought a dozen over many years, including as gifts!

Title: Works great!
Review Content: First, as recommended, I read the instruction manual (comes in English & Spanish). After peeling off the clear, plastic where the heat comes out, I removed the white plastic plug covering and just plugged this little gem in a wall outlet (NO SURGE plugs allowed). It's easy to turn knobs to desired heat level/force. My master bedroom (which can fit 3 queen sized beds, if I wanted to, lol, warmed up within minutes. I placed it on the floor,  away from any furniture/ curtains/ bookstand.  It's lightweight and easy to carry using the back handle.

Title: This little thing kicks out a lot of heat
Review Content: This heats up a well insulated room about the size of a full one car garage.  It heats so well that I often find myself becoming hot and having to turn it off for a while.  I have to turn it off and on when I need it because the automatic setting is garbage.  If it kicked on before you were cold and shut off before you got hot, it would be perfect.  But it does not do that - at all.  But if you just need a powerful and effective heater, this is for you.

Title: Very good personal heater
Review Content: This thing is powerful and quiet. I has temperature control and a saftey feature that shuts off when it hits a certain temp, which is great, but I wish it had the added safety feature of tip-over shut off like my previous heater.I live in Alaska and bought this to try and replace my ProFusion heater that I was borrowing from my sister. When she reclaimed it, I wanted another. However, I didn't immediately find it for sale so I tried this one after reading reviews. Honestly, this heater is everything it claims to be and is great. It's very quiet (more so than the ProFusion) and can put out a lot of heat. The airflow isn't as strong as the fan-based Profusion, though so if you're trying to get heat over a large area fast it'd probably be a bit slower. I've had no trouble with sparking or fires that other ceramic heaters have had, which was a big reason I went with this one over the other brands.The only problem I had, which is nothing against the product itself is that I use it very close to my body. I live in Alaska and it's pretty cold here most of the year. Rather than try and heat a whole room or house (which is expensive and hard to do) I like to put a personal sized heater next to me on the bed with the blanket tented over it (with ventilation not covered, of course). That way I get heat immediately and can warm myself up super fast. This thing puts out such high heat that even at lowest settings can scorch my skin when I do my thing. Since this isn't the way the heater was intended to be used and is no fault of it, I don't hold it against it at all. I'm just letting others know that if you're weird like me and use the heater in this way, it's too hot. Also, not having that tip over safety feature makes me worry. If I were to fall asleep and knock it over accidentally (which I've done before) then it's a worry to know it won't automatically shut off like the ProFusion would.This thing is great and does what it says it does well. I ended up finding the ProFusion and buying another, but will keep this heater for when I or someone else needs a heater to use in the normal way lol.

Title: Works as advertised, is quick to warm up
Review Content: Bought this space heater to use in a room about 12' x 15' feet I'd estimate. I've been running this guy since the end of January and it has kept the room nice and toasty. The unit is pretty compact, it's easily smaller than a gallon of milk, which is a metric I'd guess most people can visualize. The space heater has two dials, one allows you to choose your setting, and the other is a thermostat type setting.The setting options are:  - Off  - Fan  - Low Heat  - High HeatFor my room, the low heat setting has been more than enough to keep the room warm. The high heat setting draws a lot of power, and I if I place the unit on high heat and have any other power cables for speakers, a computer, or whathaveyou plugged in to the same outlet, then the surge protector will usually have to spring into action to prevent the tripping the circuit breaker. This may be due to the age of my building and potentially the power restrictions for each circuit. Regardless, the low heat setting provides a steady stream of heat.The second dial is for the thermostat and has about 11 options. The thermostat setting basically will just turn the heater on for a bit, and then turn it off for a bit in an attempt to maintain a certain temperature. It is a relatively low-tech unit, so the thermostat options are not related to temperature values, so if you want to use it you'll have to just figure out what setting works best for you via trial and error. Personally, I just turn it all the way up, even when leaving the unit on for the night.Being a ceramic heater, for the first week or so of use, there was a distinct ceramic smell that was given off when the heater was turned on. It was not an overpowering smell at all, and it didn't bother me in the slightest, it is just something to be aware of. The unit has a fan, and so there is a bit of noise, but it really isn't very loud. I think that bit of fan noise is worth the benefit of having the fan blow the hot air from the ceramic out into the room.All in all, it is a very good product and I'd recommend it to anyone looking for a small space heater.
