Title: Functional, Great Quality, Convenient, & Lowered Our Electric Bill
Review Content: I bought 2 of these heaters (both 9" under desk size) back in October 2015 and still LOVE them!! We keep one downstairs (mainly to use in our bedroom at night during the winter) and the other one in our upstairs office/loft area. Our upstairs area is roughly 500 square feet - after turning the heater on for about 10min, you can feel the warm air when you are about half way up the stairs (which are located on the opposite side of the house that the heater is plugged into). We absolutely love that the temperature is adjustable, because we can use it throughout the entire winter (outdoor temps range anywhere from below 0* to 50*) without waking up drenched in sweat. The heaters have 3 "fan" settings - 1 that is strictly a fan (i.e., emits no heat) and the other 2 settings adjust the fan speed while emitting heat (i.e., high heat & low heat).In addition to being very functional, these heaters are also extremely convenient and take up very minimal space. They are very lightweight (about 3lbs each) and have a convenient carrying handle in the back. We really appreciate the fact that the plug is 2-prong (rather than 3-prong) because our house was built back in the 1940's and still almost exclusively has 2-prong outlets (we are currently renting it, and the owners won't replace the outlets unfortunately). I'm not sure what a "good" or "low" energy consumption value would be for this type of product, but I can say that along with the outdated outlets in our house, the electrical work is "shaky" (to put it nicely) but we've had no issues with either heater blowing a fuse or heating the outlets that they are plugged into (versus my hair dryer, which seems to blow a fuse every other week). Our electrical bill has also gone down since we started using the heaters (roughly $20/month average decrease), which I'm assuming is because we now set our central air temp lower (especially at night) and use the heaters for localized room heating - this also means that the heaters paid for themselves after less than 3 months.As I said, we've had 2 of them since October 2015 (about 16 months), and both still work perfectly without any issues. I would very highly recommend these heaters to others based on functionality, durability/quality, and convenience.

Title: Portable, quiet, safe, low cost, and a thermostat that works! Heats bedroom quickly.
Review Content: UPDATE...I used this portable unit in the cold northeast New England states for light, intermittent use (3~4 times/wk, 90 min at a time, watching TV in a unheated room).After just 1.5 winter seasons, one of two heating elements has failed and the fan occasionally seizes (causes overheating and shuts down both elements).The overheating trips a circuit breaker which resets if you can get the fan to begin spinning again. But the dead heating element is fatal. The unit only produces lukewarm air and is generally useless.I have two other 1500W portable electric heaters with the identical thermostat feature -- different brands. They continue to operate without a problem.Two deal breaking "Gotchas" in 1.5 years, and no warranty service available. I threw out this heater. For this reason, I have downgraded my review from five stars to three stars. My original review appears below...___________________These tiny space heaters can heat an average room in minutes (with the door closed). Of course, any heater between 1100~1600 watts should achieve the same thing. But this one is compact, quiet and has a thermostat.Other observations:1. The case remains reasonably cool. If allowed sufficient space in front and back, I do not sense a potential fire hazard.2. The thermostat really works. But if you don't want the room heated when you leave (and if you are worried about fogetting to turn it off), consider a plug in timer. We use a Belkin model with a slide switch. It forallows for 30m, 3hr, 6hr. This also works great at night. If you are like me, you appreciate the warmth when you fall asleep, but prefer the room to be cooler as the blankets trap heat close to your body.3. There is an even smaller class of “personal warmers”. They are 600~900 watts and about the size of your hands. Those smaller warmers are not in a class with this model. They will not heat a room, but are intended to spot-heat your head and shoulders—or your legs beneath a desk.4. Electrical cost: If you live in the Northeast or if you have gas or oil heating, you may have heard that electrical appliasnces are more expensive to operate than gas or oil. While this is true, it is misleading. If your home has only one or two zones (e.g. upstairs & downstairs), a portable room heater can save lots of money. That’s because it avoids heating an entire home or an entire floor.Typical electrical rates are anywhere from 6¢ ~ 16¢ per killowatt-hour Let's say that you pay about 12c/kwh. Using this unit for 4½ hours a night to heat a medium-size bedroom (and with the door closed to contain the warm air) will cost about $1/day. Adding $30 to your monthly electric bill may sound like a significant expense, but if you lower your upstairs thermostat during the night, it reduces your winter heating bill by a greater amount. That’s because the larger space that you no longer need to heat outweighs the small cost difference between electric and gas heating.

Title: Lasko Ceramic heater
Review Content: I bought this Lasko ceramic heater three years ago on Amazon. It has held up fine with a great deal of use in the wintertime months. I keep it on the low power setting to heat the small bedroom I sleep in. I'll also take it in the bathroom sometimes and that is the only time I use the high power setting on the heater. I also use it as my main heater while I watch TV. On a cold night I put the heater pretty close to me while watching TV. Due to the heaters small size it does not do that well heating up the large living room that my TV is in. It performs better in my bedroom.This Lasko heater gets high marks for portability. This is the only smaller sized heater I own. I do wish I had a couple more of these heaters as in the winter time I am constantly unplugging the unit. I do have a couple larger oil filled metal finned heaters and they are a real chore to move around the home.The thermostat on the unit could be a bit more sensitive. Sometimes if seems a bit difficult to dial in an exact temperature setting on the dial.This heater gets excellent marks for reliability for the three years I've owned it. All to often these small inexpensive heaters do not last very long which is my main complaint. This heater is inexpensive and at the same time is very reliable. I give it a thumbs up as a purchase choice.

Title: Not 1500 Watts - High Is Only 725 Watts, Low Setting Consumes 490 Watts - Test Data Included
Review Content: After reading the positive reviews of this heater, I purchased one from Amazon.  While initially happy, I noticed that it was not tripping my circuit breaker when used with other high wattage appliances.  The sum of the rated wattages on all the devices connected to this residential circuit totaled 3000 watts.  This implied a 25 amp current draw that should have easily tripped the 15 amp circuit. The reality was that the Lasko heater consumed far less electricity than the stated 1500 watts.Given this realization, I tested the Lasko 754200 Ceramic Heater under various conditions over multiple periods of time with two different Kill-a-watt power meters. The results were somewhat surprising, indicating half the stated wattage was actually being consumed.Like any electrical heating element, the initial current and wattage will vary during the startup phase. Hence, measurements over a period of time must be made.  The test results show the average wattage consumed by the Lasko heater was 720 to 725 watts over a two hour period.Lasko Cermaic HeaterDate of test: 10/18/2011Ambient Temperature 68 degrees FHigh Setting and thermostat set to maxElap Time (h:m) ... Watts .... Amps ... KWH0:00 ................... varied .... varied .. 01:01 ................... 725 ....... 6.06 .... 0.741:43 ................... 723 ....... 6.06 .... 1.252:00 ................... 726 ....... 6.06 .... 1.44average wattage = 72010/19/2011Ambient Temperature 68 degrees FLow SettingElapsed Time .... Watts .... Amps .... KWH0:00 .... varied .... varied .... 00:30 .... 492 .... 4.07 .... 0.251:00 .... 492 .... 4.09 .... 0.491:17 .... 502 .... 4.15 .... 0.631:46 .... 493 .... 4.09 .... 0.872:00 .... 492 .... 4.09 .... 0.99Average wattage = 495(increase at t=1:17 due to cold air from open window)In another test, I forced the exhaust of another heater into the Lasko when it was on the high setting.  This caused the power consumption of the Lasko to drop into the 500s.  This suggests there is probably a thermistor circuit being crudely used to manage the heat and power consumption.  Unfortunately, whatever Lasko employed isn't working that well.Lest there be any confusion, a lower wattage heater is NOT more energy efficient or greener.  Electric heat, unlike gas forced air, is effectively 100% efficient inside the residence.  Losses occur during power transmission and production, but heat is not vented outside the structure as would occur during a combustion process.  Hence, greater wattage is better if the circuit breaker can handle it.Other problems with this heater include the brittleness of the plastic.  After a few months, the knob and grill cracked. The former had to be replaced with a spare knob from another device. Due to its overall operation, I would not suggest this heater.  Lasko could do a better job with the temperature and power control circuitry.Cons:Only 725 Watts on high and 490 watts on lowBrittle plasticPros:Inexpensive

Title: Unfortunately It Smells
Review Content: Aside from the smell, this is a nice heater. It's nice and small, yet still gets my room up to a nice temperature really quick. The temp controls work well too. It has a bit of noise from the fan as you'd expect. I was hoping this could double as a cooling fan during summer, but it's not powerful enough to reach more than a foot or so.But I just couldn't forgive the chemical odor it had. It has a noticeable plastic / chemical smell when you first start it. I heard that sometimes tempering heaters removes the smell, so I put it in a ventilated room and ran it on high for a couple of days. The smell did get better. In fact, it got to the point where I could run it without noticing the smell, unless I left the room. Coming back in, I could smell it. Which wasn't horrible. Unfortunately, even if I couldn't smell it, I still got headaches when using it. It's worth noting it's almost entirely plastic, even the fan blades. But is it the plastic, or maybe the lube for the fan that bothers me? I can't tell. I don't get headaches from it when it's not in use.It was too cheap to be worth trying to send it back (besides which, it's ins't broken, I'm just sensitive to the smell). But I was reluctant to buy something else form Amazon for the same reason. There is a happy ending though. I recently bought a Sai Oil-Filled Radiator 682101 from Home Depot (because I could easily return it if it smelled). This thing is great. It's nearly all metal (except the plastic front pieces). It's completely silent (no fans, the only sound is a slight click when the temp regulator turns on and off). And best of all, no smell! I tempered it for about 6 hours and noticed a really faint smell I couldn't quite place during the process. It's been in my room ever since, and I haven't had any headaches. The only downside is that it doesn't have numbers on it's dial, so it's tricky to figure what will maintain a comfortable temp. So if you're sensitive to chemical smells, like I am, I highly recommend the Sai.Oil-filled Radiators are supposed to be pretty good in general. So if they don't have a Sai, try a different one. Just remember, temper your heater on high, in a well ventilated place, for a couple hours before bringing it inside. Most of them have a chemical film that's supposed to prevent rust while in storage, and that's what smells until it burns off.Also, please note, a radiator is a different beast from a forced air fan entirely. They take a while to heat up a room (an hour or so). And you're better off leaving them on continuously. They also don't dry a room out the way a fan does. And you can easily make them a humidifier by placing something on top with water in it (I use a microwave safe bowl, but a metal kettle, or pan would work too).

Title: Not bad, not bad at all
Review Content: For less than $30, this is a really good heater. This heater is perfect for small rooms, like a bathroom, it will warm up the place pretty fast. Don't expect this thing to heat up a larger room (10' x 12' room) fast though, the range of heat you can feel from it is about 5 feet on low power mode, but after running it for 10-20 minutes, you will feel it getting warmer. If you like to sit down in front of the heater to get warm, you will definitely warm up!The cord is about 7ft long, was worried about the length of it since there was not anything written about it (people never cover all the details). The material its made of is pretty average, but hey that is why its $30! I really like that its compact and the design of it is quite pleasing in my opinion...some heaters can look really ugly and ruin the look of a room, not this one though.When I unboxed it, I did not get any odor or weird oil smell, it was totally fine on the first run. It did not start to work right away for me however; i plugged it in and turned it on to low power...and nothing happened, which freaked me out because I thought I got a DOA, but after a minute or so it began to power up and work. It does not do that anymore thankfully, plug it in and power it on and its working instantly :)CLARIFICATION: There is sooo a difference between lower power mode (900 watts) and high power (1200 watts). Sit in front of the heater, see what it feels like on the first mode...not bad right? Turn it on to the second...ouch hot! Not kidding, you people who say you don't feel a difference, liars!Note: Do not plug this in to a power strip, some power strips cant handle over 900 or 1200 watts, the heater takes quite a bit of power and can cause the power strip to overload. The directions state that you should plug it directly into the outlet too!

Title: Fine product, but way too noisy for us.
Review Content: I turned it on just once. A nice amount of heat came out right away, but a high noise level from the fan on all settings. Very obtrusive. The noise would have been a problem for watching TV, conducting conversations, or just about anything else. This was not a quite whir in the background; this was LOUD. We only used it for about 5 minutes, so I can't speak to other aspects of the product, other that to say that it seemed nicely made, lightweight, simple controls, unobtrusive design.

Title: This heater is amazing. It heats up my bedroom (a roughly 12' ...
Review Content: This heater is amazing. It heats up my bedroom (a roughly 12' x 15' space) VERY quickly when I turn it to the highest setting. I use it in the morning and at night when I need to change (or get out of bed!) now that the weather's turned cold. Honestly if it's near to me I feel it only takes minutes for the air to be warm enough that I don't mind changing/getting out of bed! It really does make such a difference, getting out from under the toasty covers when your roam is toasty too. Certainly made my mornings a LOT nicer. :)One thing I will mention, that while this heater does heat the air very quickly, but after turning off the air will cool somewhat quickly as well. Which I actually consider a positive, since I like my room to be a bit cooler when I go to sleep. Another reviewer posted some great instructions on how to work/set the thermostat, which is really a very nice little feature for keeping your room warm enough...when I am sitting around eg reading I want to be warm, not chilly at all or it makes me a little uncomfortable/sleepy, but also I do enjoy/prefer fresh air and find that heater-warmed air is kind of heavy/not very fresh if you know what I mean? So, a cozy sweater and socks and the heater cycling on and off is quite perfect for me. :) I also paired the heater with the(again thank you to a reviewer for instructions on how to work!), as suggested by The Sweet Home review which named this their best pick for heaters.Other reviewers talk about the noise -- honestly after 30 seconds I don't notice it anymore, it's just background/white noise, if anything it helps me concentrate a little better on what I'm doing/reading/studying :) Also it was pointed out to me that the noise (which is for me quite mild, like I said not distracting at all) can be a good thing/safety feature, since you always know when it's on. Something to consider maybe :)I've been using this heater about 6 weeks and as the weather is only getting chillier I just get more and more happy with it. It was shipped very quickly and arrived in perfect condition :)

Title: Good for the office
Review Content: I bought this space heater because I sit near the window in my office and it tends to get rather cold.  It's a solid little space heater and is supposed to be very safe as far as fire concerns go.  It heats up quickly and can be adjusted to your preference of both heat and air power (i.e. how hard it's blowing).  It even has a fan function which will hopefully be useful in the summer.There are three small problems I have noticed with the heater but they are fairly trivial and probably won't bother most people.  When I first started using the heater I noticed it had a plastic smell. I thought it was very strong but my cubicle mates didn't seem to notice and I got use to it after the first few weeks.  The other problem is that it does make some noise.  If you are looking for a silent space heater this is not it.  Again, it didn't bother those around me so and I got used to the sound after a few minutes.  It's actually a good reminder for me to not leave it running.The third problem, and this might be the most noticeable to those in a small space is that it seems to really direct the heat in one location.  It doesn't spread out and cover a lot of ground. I'm still struggling to find the right place for it; if I leave it under my desk near my legs it burns my skin, but if I move it too far away I don't feel the heat.  I've settled for keeping it on my desk and letting it blow onto my back.  When making your purchase be sure to keep in mind where you plan on putting the heater.All in all, I like this heater.  It was cheaper than other options and I think it does what it's supposed to - keep you warm!  But do keep in mind that it does have a faint odor and is a little difficult to place.

Title: Nice little heater
Review Content: I use this heater in my home office, mainly in the summer when the A/C in the rest of the house is just a little too cool for me.  It really puts out the heat, and I don't think I've ever even used the high setting!  The heat starts coming out within seconds.  It doesn't have a funny smell and it makes the whole room more comfortable.  Note:  if you have a dog, you may have to fight him for it - mine comes running the minute he hears this blowing out warm air and plops down close!

Title: Thermosat doesn't work well
Review Content: I read the reviews, and chose to buy it.  I'm using it in my home office, so that I don't have to heat the whole house all day, just to stay warm in my office with the door closed.  Let me say that the heat output of this little thing is really surprising.  I keep the house cool, like around 66 to 67 overnight because we sleep better when it's cool.  If I turn the furnace on in the morning, it takes an hour or two to warm the house so that my office is at around 70.Since I got this little device, I start my work and turn on the heater, and the office is warm in about 20 to 30 minutes, without a problem.  The fan makes some noise, but it's not really bothersome.  I have had the thermostat set on about level 1.5 to 2 for over a week.  When I turn it on, the temp in the room comes up to about 71 to 72.  Through the day, the heater cycles on and off, as expected.  However, the room gradually warms more and more.  If I don't touch it, by mid afternoon, the office is up to a balmy 78, at which point if I don't turn it down, my family may find me soaked in sweat in my pajamas!I don't understand how it keeps getting warmer, and I've tried adjusting through the day to get to a stable temp, but it just doesn't do that.  So, I have gotten into the habit of turning it off around 2 or 3pm, and letting the room gradually cool.  For it's cost, this works great.  I will have to wait a month or two to see if it actually does save on the heating bill, but I'm pretty sure that it will.  The rest of the house remains cool, saving on heat during the day, and cooling at night.  Plus, it was inexpensive.Otherwise, the quality seems good and I'm happy with the purchase.

Title: Mostly ineffective by year 6, but it was a good run.
Review Content: For a small electric heater, this thing is awesome. It has done a great job for me for over 2 years. One other great thing is that you can sorta clean it without opening it. After unplugging it, I held it face up and sprayed into the front grate with air in a can, and the air pushed the globs of dust to the back part of the heater where I was able to take the dust out with a cue tip.If you want to make your room more toasty during those cold winter nights, I strongly recommend this product.In addition, I should note that the heater has a power '1' setting and a power '2' setting; the power '2' setting might give off a bit of a burning smell, but there is no reason to ever use the power '2' setting. The longevity of my heater might be attributed to the fact that I use setting '1' only. I'm willing to bet that some of the negative reviews indicating poor quality were a result of people using power setting '2'. I personally recommend not using the maximum setting on any electrical item: Fan, Air Conditioner, Heater, Refrigerator, etc.2014 update and adjustment from 5 stars to 4 stars:This is the 6th winter I'm using this heater, and the heat function works at maybe 25% strength of what it used to be. It was wrapped in plastic over the winters, and this type of longevity for this product exceeds expectations based on the price point. The main reason for the adjustment to 4 stars is that the thermostat just didn't work as well by the 3rd year - I'd wake up to being uncomfortable and have to turn the thermostat lower, then wake up 2 hours later because it was too cold in my room.It's a very good product. Wrap it in plastic during winters, and NEVER use the 2 setting (never use highest setting on any electronic if you want it to last long.)12/14 update - bought a new one, and didn't realize how much power this thing has considering the price point. For under $30 this thing heats up a medium sized room. So it's apparent as it gets older, the intensity declines, but it's very gradual; it does the job for 4-5 years.  I'm going to leave this at 5 stars as long as the thermostat works for at least 2 years, like the last one did.

Title: Wee heater with BIG warmth!
Review Content: There are two kinds of space heaters in the world: the kind that heat rooms and the kind that heat people. This teeny unit can actually do both, provided that you eithera) point it directly at you, reasonably nearby orb) are in an incredibly small room.I had originally bought this little thing to keep me from freezing to death in my small (9x10-ish, w/low-ceilings) Upstate NY office. Oil was crazy expensive that year so we switched to a wood burning stove but the heat didn't make it to my upstairs batcave of an office. But with this dreamy thing under my desk I would warm up in minutes, even with the door open. If I closed the door? Toasty all over in about an hour. I'm talking about a poorly insulated, drafty, single-pane windowed room in a 100 year-old house with NO other heat source. Granted, a tiny, tiny room, but still. For a $20 heater, I was very pleased.Now I've moved way farther South where we don't have 20F December days, BUT we do have another 100 year-old house, this time with very high ceilings, drafty windows, zero insulation and no heat source at all (I know, I know: we can really pick 'em). When it's 55F outside w/100% humidity it's an intolerable 45F inside. Seriously. It's 45F in my livingroom. It stinks.The wee Lasko is NOT capable of heating the comparatively large rooms in this house BUT it is perfectly capable of keeping me warm enough to type this review. It's on it's highest setting (really the "adjustable thermostat" claim is silly. It's essentially just "really hot" or "less-really hot". There's no middle ground) and it's aimed at my mid-section. When I step away from my desk I simply turn it off. No sense running it when I'm not sitting in front of it. Just a waste of energy.I generally run it for several hours at a time and it does not get hot on the sides or top. The unit seems safe enough, but I'm not sure I'd sleep with it on. Might worry me a little. It's not exactly gorgeous, but what space heater is? It's so little that it doesn't matter what it looks like. You'll forget it's there.Don't expect this thing to replace your central heating, if you're lucky enough to have it, but it's exactly the right heater to heat YOU wherever you may be sitting or standing.

Title: Ours only lasted 3 years.
Review Content: We purchased this model  from Amazon in 2021 and it is no longer working. The fan is really slow, smells like burning wire and getting to hot on the outside. so I just stopped using it. We use it only 4 months out a year and probable 20 minutes a day to heat up our bathroom. I just repurchased another one from Amazon as they really work good when they are working. So I gave it a three based on the life span of this little heater.

We use it only 4 months out a year and probable 20 minutes a day to heat up our bathroom. I just repurchased another one from Amazon as they really work good when they are working. So I gave it a three based on the life span of this little heater.

Title: Exceeds even my fussy expectations!
Review Content: My wife and I are extremely pleased with this heater.  It is attractive, has a very small footprint and great safety and adjustability features.  And does it ever put out the heat!  The fan speed is adjustable and so is the heat intensity.There is a lot of misunderstanding about portable electric space heaters.  You can pay a LOT more for a much more expensive heater which will falsely claim to heat better, but because ALL electric space heaters are 100% efficient, even the most expensive will cost exactly the same to operate per BTU of output.  And nearly all 15 amp heaters will have the same maximum heat output, regardless of what you pay.  So while it is often true that the more you pay, the more you get but that is simply not true when it comes to electric space heaters.  Now if you are seeking additional features, paying more will get you more features,  but ask yourself if you really need all those features.  Take oscillating for example, a feature that rotates the heater about 180 degrees.  This heater does not heave that.  But thanks to physics, the hot air blowing out of this heater will quickly move toward cooler air in the room.  There are also a few reviews attacking this heater for not having safety features.  The ONLY safety feature lacking on this heater is tip over off.  If you think your kids or dogs, for example, might tip this heater over, then do not buy this heater.  But if you want the convenience of being able to use this heater with say Alexa, this is one of the few heaters that will work with Alexa because it does NOT have that safety feature.  This heater is very stable and would be difficult to tip over, but if picked up and then turned down, it can certainly be tipped over.  Another reviewer claimed that his melted down.  If that really did happen, it was surely an aberration based on the huge number of these heaters that have been sold and the vast majority of positive reviews.

Title: Keeps shutting off (UPDATED) and light won't go off (ADDED)
Review Content: Further UPDATE: The red light won't go off without unplugging the unit (which requires that I crawl under my desk, which is not practicable given how often I need to turn it on and off).  I worry that if the light's on, maybe the heater's still on even if the fan's off.  So between that and the fact that when it's working, the controls don't seem to actually control the fan or temperature, it would better to just have one on/off toggle that effectively controlled everything including the light.Since the unit can't be used with an extension cord or power strip, a much longer cord would also be helpful.In sum, this unit is turning out to be almost completely useless to me.  I think the previously time, I ordered the more expensive model which (I failed to realize when I ordered this one) had a longer extension cord and which would also work much longer with a power strip (though I now realize I probably shouldn't have been plugging the unit into one).UPDATE: Re- my complaint that the unit keeps shutting off, I now understand that these things need to be plugged directly into the wall, rather than into a surge protector or extension cord – this limitation is set out in the user guide available on the product page as a pdf.First, I don't notice any difference in the gradations of heat and fan power indicated by the controls; the thing is either on or its not on.  Second, it won't stay on for more than a few moments if used with an extension cord or surge protector.  That means I need to crawl all the way under my desk if I want to turn it on or off – not ideal.I like the heater in all other ways, but these factors basically make the thing almost unusable.  Unfortunately although I just opened the box today, I bought it a while ago, so it's too late to return it.

Title: Affordable and good - 5 years and still working!
Review Content: I have been using this heater for almost one week so far.  It has been keeping my 11 x 17 room warm.  This is my first portable/space heater I own.  I live in a condo and there's always central heat/AC but this year for some reason they turned off our heat in April to change over to AC.  It has been in the 50F-60F's, sometimes in 40's overnight.  That is not warm enough for me.  I was hesitant to take a chance on this because it's under $25.  However, due to reviews I decided why not.  Here are my thoughts:Pros-Works pretty well for my room size (11x17).-Warms up quickly in closed spaces-Affordable-No smell/odor (only slightly at beginning)Cons-Sometimes there is slight vibrations/rattle-Fan could be loud to some but it's white noise to me-Red light remains on even when it is turned off-Confusing thermostat settings-Their "convenient" carrying handle is pretty shallow.  Be careful and hold the bottom-I think the cord is 6ft (sounds long) but I wish it was longerFinal ThoughtsI am happy with my purchase.  I hope it lasts a long time.  I cannot really tell the difference between settings 1 (900W) and 2 (1500W).  I think "2" feels hotter.  I leave it on "1" just to be safe.  I always unplug when it is not in use, or if I am away from my room for a while.  Just to be safe, you never know if it tips over or burns!  Instructions says do NOT use in bathrooms.  Also, do not use extension cords.  Plug directly into outlet.---------------------June 11, 2021 - UPDATEIt is still working just fine!

Title: Good heater for indoor spaces
Review Content: I have a work space in a separate building from my main house on my property and the only climate control is a window unit and a wall heater that isn't really powerful enough to warm up the whole room. I put this little heater right next to my feet while I was at my computer and I quickly realized it was a little more power than I needed. I then put it on the low heat setting and turned it away from my feet so it would just indirectly heat up the entire area under my work desk and it did a wonderful job. Got me through the whole winter.I also have a much older Lasko ceramic heater that appears to be the exact same as this one except a solid black instead of grey, and I've been running it for 4 months out of the year almost constantly for 5 years now in my humid 5' x 7' greenhouse and its still going strong.I should mention that I don't actually use the built in thermostat on either of my heaters so I cant really say how accurate it is, but my reasoning is for warming the underside of my desk if its too hot i just bend down and turn it off and for my greenhouse i have a thermostat on the wall that controls everything so i maxed out the heaters built in thermostat and I just let my own external thermostat decide when to turn it on and off.I should also mention that if you are trying to stay warm outside on a patio in the wind or anywhere other than indoors then this wouldn't be the right heater for you. I tried using mine for that but i discovered that you really need a radiant heater with big glowing red hot coils for that sort of thing. This heater is better for inside spaces because it performs well and there should be less of a fire hazard. I still keep it away from fabric though just to be safe.

Title: The little heater that could
Review Content: Let me first say that I was skeptical at first about how much this little thing could do. So I have tested it out for the past week and I have been nothing short of stunned at how well this heater performs.The house I am renting right now is horribly insulated...I mean, it just hardly has any at all. So, at night, the house either gets really cold (if I turn the thermostat down), or my utility bill goes "out the roof". As a compromise, I wanted to find a way to only heat the room I was using, especially at night. The first night I got this heater, I turned my thermostat down to 46...yes, 46. I put old towels in the cracks at the bottom of the door to the entrance of my room and the door that leads to my bathroom to really trap in as much warm air as possible. I turned on this little guy and went to sleep.About 4 AM, I woke up and I was HOT. The temperature outside the house dropped down to 11 degrees that night, the rest of the house was down to the 46 degrees, but this heater had managed to warm my entire bedroom up to not only where it was a cozy temperature, but I had to actually turn it DOWN to the lower setting because it was too warm for me to sleep comfortably. I have been doing the same thing for about a week now and I have absolutely no complaints. Amazing heater for warming up a single room!Also, some may complain about the lack of a "safety feature" where the heater cuts off when/if it is tipped over. Well, for me personally this is a huge plus because I was not able to prop my other heater down towards the tile to warm up my bathroom floor in the mornings. When tilted downward a little bit, It does a pretty good job at pushing the warm air across the tiles and keeps them from being freezing cold.All in all, a wonderful bargain!

Title: Lacks the safety feature of current ceramic heater.
Review Content: This is a nice standard ceramic space heater. Has 2 dials: i) The Thermostat dial ii) The Heat dial.Though the fan is audible, but is is not loud like the other "Brightown ceramic heater" I have.Brightown heater for the win. Reasons: 1) Comes with a handle that makes it portable and  easy to carry around2) Tip-Over switch. For me this has become a deal breaker. A tip over switch guarantees the heater will trip off when it falls on it's face. Thus minimizing the  risk of a fire hazard. This safety feature is absent in this LASKO heater brand.Matter of fact, I would recommend any heater that comes with this feature over this Lasko model.USAGE TIPS:I notice a lot of space heater reviews have a common complaint, which is the heater burnt out and stopped working. Now I have learnt from the school of hard knocks how to prolong the longevity of these heaters.1) This like I said earlier is a 2 dial heater. One dial is a MODE the second dial a Heat THERMOSTAT. Now on the mode dial we have Three settings: An off setting, Fan setting, MEDIUM HEAT I and the highest setting HEAT II.NOTE: Do NOT set it at HIGH Heat II. And do NOT set the thermostat at the highest setting either. Doing so near guarantees the heater will burn out much sooner. I live in Wisconsin, so I know what cold weather is like, but I always set the Space heater at MEDIUM HEAT I, and the thermostat at the midway point or marginally above that. And it heats my room just fine.This setting I use also ensures that the plug or the socket itself is less likely to burn/blow. Something that happened frequently when the settings were high in previous heaters I owned.Overall, a decent heater. But I still suggest you go for the one with a Tip-Over switch.That is pretty much my review of this heater. Hope this was helpful.

Title: Very powerful little heater
Review Content: I was skeptical when I ordered it. It's small and portable, and I watch the temperature in the room rise quickly. It's almost overkill in my bathroom, works great in my bedroom at a low setting. Experimenting with settings I've learned to maintain the temperature I like (in the beginning I was overheated). I remember to shut it off before unplugging and moving it, as that was in the product warnings. I've had a Lasko fan and was not impressed, but this item is surprising. I'm buying a second because I move it around a lot. For under $50 for 2 heaters, I don't see how spending $80 on a bigger one that I won't want to move around makes a lot of sense. I've been using it over a month, totally satisfied. Updating: I bought these in 2015 and still use them. They could be a fire hazard if you use them full power, and unattended. I don’t do that. I recommend a low setting, it will turn off when it satisfies the thermostat. There are few things I have that are still reliable and these save me money on heating. I don’t need the whole house heated to a comfortable temperature. So I have one of these in the bathroom and one in the living room to take the chill off. I’m careful to not leave them on.It's 2023, I bought 2 in 2015, they are STILL working well. I use in bathrooms and when I have a chill rather than turn up the heat. Space heaters require vigilance to be safe. I would not put it on a rug, for example. That being said, these are wonderful for my purposes. I would never have imagined an appliance that costs $30 to last so long, I’m very satisfied. This year, colder than usual, I’m using it more. I expect to buy another soon, as they definitely start retaining dust, one has started to have a slight burning odor if used longer than an hour on high.

Title: Great space heater for small offices
Review Content: I've been using the Lasko space heater, and it's been an excellent addition to my office & home. The heater is compact yet powerful, quickly warming up a room without taking up much space. It has adjustable thermostat settings, which allows for precise control over the temperature. I also appreciate the built-in safety features, like the overheat protection and cool-touch exterior, which give me peace of mind when using it. The noise level is minimal, making it perfect for use in a bedroom or office. Overall, it's a reliable, efficient heater that I would highly recommend.

Title: This is the first heater I've ever bought and was suggested to get something like this from a friend to save money on my ...
Review Content: So I've had this thing a few months now and have had the chance to really judge it. This is the first heater I've ever bought and was suggested to get something like this from a friend to save money on my electric bill. The amount of money I have saved is pretty great. Normally around winter time, using the heater in my apartment would rank up my electric bill to about 120-130 dollars (normally it's like 30-40 during the summer). Using this, it dropped the price down to about 70-80 on my bill.As far as heat and usage goes, I'm unsure how reliable this thing is going to be in the long run. Again it's my first heater I've bought so I don't know if this is normal, but I would want to say this thing is kind of buggy when it comes to operating. For example one time, the thing wouldn't turn on in normal fan mode or at the normal fan + heat mode. It would only turn on when it was high fan + heat. Also there were times where I put the heat on low and it wouldn't turn on at all, but if I turned up the heat it would eventually come on around the half way point. Currently it's sitting across from me on the other side of the room and as of right now, the settings for fan + heat seem to operate the same as high fan + heat. However I do have the thing running a lot right now cause it's cold where I am so it's been running very often like this ever since I bought it back some months ago. I dunno if it'll last a year though, we'll see. If it doesn't I'll probably pick up something else to last me during the winter.

Again it's my first heater I've bought so I don't know if this is normal, but I would want to say this thing is kind of buggy when it comes to operating. For example one time, the thing wouldn't turn on in normal fan mode or at the normal fan + heat mode. It would only turn on when it was high fan + heat. Also there were times where I put the heat on low and it wouldn't turn on at all, but if I turned up the heat it would eventually come on around the half way point. Currently it's sitting across from me on the other side of the room and as of right now, the settings for fan + heat seem to operate the same as high fan + heat. However I do have the thing running a lot right now cause it's cold where I am so it's been running very often like this ever since I bought it back some months ago. I dunno if it'll last a year though, we'll see. If it doesn't I'll probably pick up something else to last me during the winter.

Title: A little dynamo!!
Review Content: When I needed some space heaters, I turned to the web and to Amazon to read reviews, like I do with most everything I buy.  This Lasko heater got rave reviews, but I thought it was too small for what I needed -- using it to heat an average-sized room instead of relying on my oil furnace (I'm hoping to save money, as oil's price is ridiculous).  But I bought it anyway, and today I received my second one!  This little thing is truly amazing to me.  I can just compare it to all that heat that comes out of a little hair dryer.Let me give you an example.  I sleep without any heat at all in the house, and two nights ago, the outside temperature got down into the 30's.  I woke up, and the thermostat in my living room read 50 degrees.  I cut on my Lasko heater, and, within 10 minutes, the room was a toasty 68 degrees!  I actually used it to heat up the room, while an oil-filled radiator heater was just clicking and clacking and starting to heat up a bit.  (I then used the radiator to maintain the heat that the Lasko produced.)Another observation is that the cord is pretty thick and it doesn't get very hot when in use like another heater I have.  I read that it's normal for cords on heaters to get a little warm, but I still don't like that because it makes me feel that it could overheat and catch fire.This heater is much smaller than I thought it was, and is just a little bigger than a 5 lb bag of flour.  It is easy to carry around with the handle area in the back of the unit, and it doesn't get hot to the touch, so you can pick it up right after you turn it off.  The back of the unit accumulates dust, and you can vacuum off the grate.  There are 3 settings:  fan only, low, and high.  Another dial adjusts the temperature up or down, and a nice feature is that you can adjust the temp along a whole dial, instead of in 5-degree increments like some other heaters.I will recommemd this heater to anyone and everyone!

Title: Great little heater
Review Content: Very quality heater; small but punch real hard in terms of heating rooms. Mine is 11 plus years now and still works. Quality product.
Manually Corrected Review Content: Very quality heater; small but punch real hard in terms of heating rooms. Mine is 11 plus years now and still works. Quality product.

Title: Good price, puts out plenty of heat, no issues yet
Review Content: Update: After owning two of these heaters for around two years one of them suddenly stopped working. It gets power but the unit doesn't actually start running. I sent an email to Lasko support who responded within a day or so and asked me to call their customer support line instead, even though I included all the details of the heater (serial #, model, Amazon invoice #) in the email which was slightly annoying.In the end I decided it wasn't worth the hassle going through that process to replace a cheap space heater so I just trashed it and bought a new one, albeit of a different brand. The second one is still going strong, however.Decided to take one star off my review ("I like it" - which I still do - instead of "I love it") to accurately represent how I feel about the heater.-----------------------------------------------I've been using this heater for hours at a time, most days for several months and it hasn't had a single issue. Puts out the perfect amount of heat to keep a medium-sized room warm, although I usually have it on the floor pointed right at my feet because I'm apparently some sort of lizard-person who enjoys that sort of thing.My wife also has one, and uses it down the hall from me (we both work from home). Between the two of them, our upstairs usually ends up 5+ degrees warmer than our downstairs, so they definitely make a difference. For the price I've been very satisfied.It'll be interesting to see how long they last at this level of use, considering we have a dog that sheds like crazy - which means the heater is probably getting a fair amount of hair/dust in it.

Title: not for everyone
Review Content: Just received this item and it works well.  Two features I don't like:  If plugged in, the light is always on so I can't tell from a distance if it is running.  It does not have auto stop if knocked over which I feel is an important safety feature.  Would have bought a different heater if I had known about these features.  My previous Lasko did have the auto turn off.

Title: First impression. not great, but it seems like it will work for me
Review Content: This review is after only a few minutes of useUse case:() I am only going to use this 10 minutes every morning as a get-out-of-bed aid.Pros:() Gets hot fast.() Gets very hot.Cons:() Fan is inadequate. I setup a second fan behind the device to help move the heat. The heat needs to go about 2.5 feet.() Plug gets warm where it plugs in within a minute of starting.() It has one temperature. Full on. The left knob turns it off, then has 2 fan settings (barely anything, and slow)() It gives off an electronics cooking smell.() Summary:For me this will work. I've got it setup with a timer and it will run for under 10 minutes, and I've got it in a clear area with nothing around it. So far it pours out the heat.  With a second fan behind it on low, the air is still very warmI don't expect this to last long.  Maybe it will for me but I get the feeling that since it goes full bore all the time when on, that at some point somethings going to give since when it turns off the fan goes off too. There's no cool down.Also it's all plastic.  I've had other heaters before but this is my first plastic one.  The metal one that I had had a real fan and since it was metal I was much less worried about something going bad inside.If you do buy this I would recommend running it with a second fan behind it and leaving that fan on for a bit after you turn this off to help disperse the heat.Definitely do not run this where it's sitting next to anything flammable.

Title: Fantastic little heater for Work and Home
Review Content: Recommend – Yes- would recommendPurchased- Via Amazon in December 2015. I’ve been using the heater solidly for 10 months.I’ve generally used the heater to heat, but the fan option is a surprise added bonus!Used- My primary use of the heater was to stay warm at work. I work in a large room with an (extremely!) active air conditioner. Even though the work space is large, this heater was strong enough to keep me toasty throughout the day. I use the heater on a daily basis, year round.Settings used- I generally kept it running on the lower of the two (speed/strength?) settings. However, when I took the heater home with me over the Christmas holiday, I was able to heat my bedroom using the higher.Additionally, I think the air blows both out and up. At work, I had the most success placing it on a low shelf to my side, but not directly on the floor because the fan air hits at kind-of a strange angle. On the floor it seemed to blow directly in my face, but when placed higher, I didn’t have the same problem.Problems- After using the heater for a couple of months, the lower of the two settings stopped working and the heater would only fan out cold air. I considered sending the heater back for a replacement or repair but, to be frank, I was lazy and the higher setting still worked. After a couple weeks the lower speed started heating again and I haven’t had the same problem again.Bonus: Our air conditioner stopped working for a couple days in the middle of summer. The fan-only setting was a real life saver.I love this little heater and would certainly buy it again. We recently purchased a second to be used by my husband while he travels in Alaska.

Title: How to fix when it stops working:
Review Content: I've had my heater for a few years, but now I live in my camper year round in Utah, and I started using this as my sole heat-source (minus an electric blanket) once the weather started getting cold. It's December first and temps are dropping down into the 20's, maybe teens at night. It's been pretty decent. But tonight it stopped working. I got worried and began investigating.Symptoms:The light was on, and I could hear the thermostat mechanism engage when I adjusted the temperature setting, but no fan and no heating element response.Diagnosis:Unplugged, replugged, flipped the dials in all combinations... Nothing. The internet said their fan clogged with dust, disabling the blower, so I gave it a shot. (spoiler:) Turns out this was in fact the culprit. It looked like someone had transplanted a month's worth of dryer lint to the back of the heating element. It peeled off in one sheet.Procedure:The fan housing uses what's called a "spanner screw" for 2 of the 4 corners. Imagine a flathead screw with a dot of metal in the middle so a normal screw driver won't fit into it. My solution: find a flat-head screw driver and use a rotary tool with a cutting disc to cut out the middle of the tip of the screwdriver so it can fit into the spanner screw. Took only a few seconds. You can use a file, but it might take longer. See drawing below:||_||  ||  ||  ||Pull apart the housing and you'll see the heating element has 4 plastic retainer clips that hold it in place. You'll need to access the rear of it for cleaning, so bend these back as you lift the heating element out. Clean the back of the element and any loose dust throughout the housing, replace parts in reverse order, throw the 2 spanner screws away, and use the 2 normal screws in opposite corners to make next time easier.Nice little safety feature to keep the clogged element from catching fire, but not sure why need need for the safety-spanner screw. Anyway, hope someone finds this useful.

Title: Still working 5 years later!
Review Content: I bought this in 2017 for my office space.  I used I t almost every day in the winter.  Most of the time,  i kept the fan low and at the second heat notch because this thing can put out heat!My coworkers would use it while i was gone to heat an entire room in a trailer office (room sizes est 12x12 foot and right next to the hallway door that goes outside.... and is opening constantly by people coming and going). They would cook the room into a sauna!This last winter,  ive used it in my basement office area.  The basement is typically cool and doesn't have much heat from the hvac system.  If i forget to turn this heater off, it will keep the entire basement warm.The first 2 years, i used this heater in Colorado, the last 3 years as been in Wisconsin.All in all, i am very impressed and hope they didn't change anything from 2017!

Title: If you are looking for a cab heater... buy this instead.
Review Content: I don't normally write reviews, but if anyone is looking for a cheap alternative to a truck or car cab heater this is your buy.  I bolted this thing to a piece of plywood (8" x 20") and wedged the other end of the board between my rear seats, so that the heater is centered in the car's interior and is touching nothing upholstered (in the event of a malfunction causing it to overheat).  I then ran a weatherproof extension cord from my garage to the car.  On the lowest setting (fan speed 1, thermostat turned 3/4 of the way down) this thing blasts enough heat to keep all six windows crystal clear during an overnight snow shower!  The unit itself is cool to the touch even after running for several hours (due to the ceramic heating element) and is designed to trip itself and shut down in the event of a malfunction.  For added precaution I also ran it into a GFCI plug to avoid an electrical short creating a fire hazard.I am aware this is not what the item is originally designed for, but considering an average cab heater = $200 - 300 and this is like 30$, if you take a few precautions and use your head when setting it up it is well worth the savings.  I can literally unplug the cord, get into my car and take off, even during snow or freezing conditions that normally require 5-10 min of warm-up time (not to mention scraping the windows or shoveling off the snow).For the extension cord, make sure you use a 14 gauge (25' run) or 12 gauge (longer runs) cord designed for outside use.  This unit has a 1100/1500 watt motor (depending on the fan speed) so using a thinner cord could overburden it and cause problems.

Title: New use: drying clothes in winter in small laundry room.
Review Content: Nice little heater. I have used it in the kitchen at the table where I do my computer/paper work to keep my feet from freezing on the tile floor in the winter.Neatest use I have found for it is in the laundry room. Several things need to be hung to dry in the coldest dampest room in my house, built out under the eves off the kitchen. I have places to hang a few things, so I put them up as usual. Then I turned on the heater per instructions to sort of a medium high setting. After I while, I adjusted the thermostat downward till it kicked off the heat. In the morning my clothes were dry (usually this time of year two or three days) and I left the door open to the kitchen to let some of the heat flow into the kitchen. Next time, I do not to think I need it up quite so high as I did. maybe a "50%" instead of a "70%".I'm using the odd terminology because you must adjust the thermostat manually. It obviously cannot tell the temperature in the room, so you are just guessing how warm is warm enough, then turning it down to maintain. Which  means come back to it or it will keep blasting out high heat for a very, very long time. Appropriate in the frozen North, probably. In a mountain cabin where the fireplace heat can't reach, but not for a tiny laundry room. The need to turn it down when it seems warm enough, is why I deducted one star. It requires attention for a while before can leave it  to work alone.Obviously, do not leave plugged in when leaving the hose or near drapes, christmas trees, etc. It's very handy for certain things.

Title: A very hot hot heater!
Review Content: I was looking for a heater to replace a 15-year old portable heater by Holmes.  The Holmes heater gave me great service, but a switch went on it and it just wasn't worth fixing.  I initially looked at the Nikko Lighting which had a few more features than this one by Lasko, but it is $60. This one from Lasko is only $25.  The Nikko Lighting showed a picture of them doing a comparison of three heaters and their temperature output.  They rated the Nikko at 240 degrees and "a popular heater" at 130 degrees output.  Interestingly, the picture they used for the "popular heater" looks just like this Lasko 754200, although they do not say it.  So, upon receiving this heater and plugging it in, I immediately turned it on high.  This thing is hot!  It was putting heat out so hot, I had to move back from it.  I grabbed a thermometer and placed it in front of this Lasko heater and watched the needle on the dial rise.  My thermometer only goes to 220 degrees.  As you can see in the picture, the needle was well above the 220 degree mark.  I was back about a half foot when I took the reading.  For the price of the Lasko I can purchase two and still have money left over vs. the cost of the Nikko Lighting.  Although the Nikko Lighting has a couple additional features, to me those features are not worth the price difference.  The Lasko also comes with a three year warranty vs. a one year warranty for the Nikko.  This Lasko has a very quiet gentle fan. It is not loud like my old Holmes heater.  Time will tell if I can get 15-years out of this one, but so far, I am impressed with it's performance.

Title: Perfect for heating a small bathroom.

Title: Works When It Wants to OR With  a Little Abuse OR Some Jerry-Rigging
Review Content: I received delivery of this heater yesterday (11/10/23) and it did NOT work properly from day one.It heated for about 10 minutes (IF you don't touch it, bump it); then turned off. I mean all the way off---the indicator light goes out also.I unplugged/re-plugged the unit---nothing. I readjusted the ON/OFF and temperature knobs--nothing. I unplugged/re-plugging, turned the temperature knob to "Min" setting, the ON/OFF switch to "Off", and waited for 1, 5, 10...minutes--NOTHING!For some unknown reason, I decided to shake and tap the unit on a hard surface and, the indicator light turned on, and the heating cycle began.I'm thinking something is loose inside the unit housing. Since this item is on the low end; I didn't have high expectations. I did hope it would satisfy the basic requirement of providing some heat...consistently for a few days...maybe a couple of weeks.  But, I believe I have a defective product and, I'll be sending it back. No, I  do not recommend this product.UPDATE:I discovered what the issue was/is with this heater. There is a problem with the 'button' on the bottom of the unit that controls the 'tip-over' safety feature. The 'button' does not appear to be fully extended so that it rests on the surface it's resting. So, it's always up and away from the surface and thinks the unit has been tipped thus, the unit will NOT start --- it's in perpetual shutdown mode. What I had to do was find something to place on the resting surface (my desk), under the 'tip-over' button.This is not how this product is supposed to operate. So, no, my rating (of one (1)) is still valid. I cannot recommend this product.

Title: Decent small heater for utility use
Review Content: I had this one 17 months before it failed.  (The ALL will fail.  Every one)  Have quite the experience with many of these kinds of heaters.)  That is more than most of the others we have tried.  During that time it worked perfectly.In these heaters, there are two ways they usually fail.  1) the heat sensor goes out and will not allow the heater to activate. (try and find that part!)  2) it will develop an "electrical smell" indicating something is definitely wrong and therefore not safe to use (this was symptom on this one that I am replacing).  Since I got 17 months out of the last one, going to try again.

Title: Poor remote/plug got very hot
Review Content: The remote did not come with a CR 2025 battery included.  Then, to access the battery compartment on the remote, you had to remove an incredibly tiny Phillips head screw with an incredibly tiny Phillips head screwdriver.  I was just lucky enough to have both the required battery and necessary screwdriver on hand. Once I got the remote functioning, though, so far I have found the heater puts out a good amount of very hot air. The hot air production is much better than I had from my last space heater. In an update of my review, when the heater is turned on, it comes on at the highest power setting.  I found that after 15 or 20 minutes on the highest power setting, the heater's plug got so hot it threw the breaker switch on the power strip it was plugged into. I found that to be a concern.

Title: Gets hotter faster, its quieter, and it has good safety features-I made a good choice!
Review Content: I received my B & D ceramic heater today.  I plugged in the B & D and turned it on to high, WHAT I NOTICED: the air got hot immediately.  Also, I noticed that the fan was stronger and quieter than my other heater (same size).  Don't listen to anyone else that says the fan is loud, because I guarantee that mine is quiet!  My other heter, you can't feel the fan over 2 feet from the heater, but the B & D heater fan throws the heat further.  I am going to end this review right here.  I love my B & D - Black and Decker heater.  I was kicking myself for paying slightly more for it than some other cheaper models.  But, usually B & D produces good products, so I took a chance, and I am satisfied now that I made the right choice.  It will go in the closet for now because I live in Florida and will only need it for about 2 weeks in January and February.  But, I can rest easy knowing that when I pull it out of the closet, I'll be able to count on it when the time comes to use it.- - and the fan really is quieter, I guess that I got a good one!

Title: Great Value - Good Brand
Review Content: I have been using this little heater for quite a few days now. I like that it is the old fashioned manual dials. The auto shut-off is based on a little 'foot' on the bottom of the heater - so it will no operate unless this is on a fairly smooth surface. I tried placing it on a footstool I have that has a textured surface and it did not keep the foot sensor depressed and would not turn on...as soon as it was on a smooth surface - Voila - worked perfectly. The white does have a tendency to yellow when exposed to heat. This is Black and Decker folks - it is safe! But the white will turn after exposed to high heat so do not expect it to look pristine after running it for some time. Overall I am very pleased for the money - it does a nice job of warming up my feet and legs while working at my desk.

Title: Toasty!
Review Content: Highly effective at heating small rooms.  I highly recommend this product.I also really appreciate it's auto-shutoff feature, should it fall over.  (It doesn't even have to fall over for it to shutoff, even a good shake or wobble will make it temporarily stop.)

Title: Little Dynamo
Review Content: We use this heater to heat a small (6' by 9')l bathroom and a medium sized office(10' by 12') .  This model is light weight and super easy to transport, so no problem moving it between these two locations. Most of the time we use it on the low (750 wqtt) setting, which is sufficient for small to mdium sized rooms. It heats up areas of this size in a matter of minutes. The safety features take a second to get used to. (When i first took it out of the box to try it out I thought it was broken!) but it must be set on a completely flat surface in order to operate. This is the safety 'tip-over' feature.  Well constructed and attractive, it looks like it should last for years. Welcome to the family!

Title: Awesome affordable heater
Review Content: I work in a warehouse in the Northeast. In the winter the temperatures can be brutal to work in especially when our heating system is constantly giving out. Sometimes I find myself along with coworkers in the breakroom multiple times a day just to escape the cold, which doesn't help productivity too much. I decided to purchase this desktop heater and its FANTASTIC! I keep it close by my workspace and it keeps my entire area warm and works within minutes. It's powerful and effective and really helps us get back on track with work. I love how its not so big so it doesn't take up too much space. It really works great.  You gotta try this out if you have any heating issues. It fits right on the corner of the desk and reaches throughout. Also love the price on this  5 STARS

Title: Best little heater ever owned.
Review Content: After some extensive research for 3 days on electric heaters, reading reviews, specs and  safety concerns, I choose the Black & Decker Ceramic Heater. I must have looked at over 200 heaters and found this one to be the safest and most reliable heater out there. The heater is very powerful with very good air flow. I only need to use it on low heat setting for heating up a small barn with plants growing in it. The barn is about 10 X 12 with vents on both sides. Heats the barn up from 50 degrees to about 70 degrees in 5 minutes ON LOW and keeps it around that temperature all night. The company Black & Decker has been around for many years so its a name you can trust.

Title: A Small-sized and light-weighed heater
Review Content: This is a small sized and weighted heater heater. It can be easily transported between rooms in your house. The fan inside is very strong so the heat generated by the blowing wind can be felt immediately. What I am concerning is the light weight. It could tip over if not securely placed on a fluffy carpet. To prevent it from happening, the heater is equipped with a tip-over safety feature: Once the heater is tipped over, an internal switch will automatically shut the heater off. In addition, the cost should be lowered. After all it is a portable heater.

Title: Works well but louder than a previous heater I had...

That being said, it is much louder than my old heater, and the on light stays on even if you aren't running the heater.  I wish the light would only come on if the heater is turned on--not to indicate that it is plugged in.

Title: Product is horriable
Review Content: I bought this heater on 6/11/19 I've used it about 15 time in Miami you don't really need heaters but I bought for my office.  From day 1 I've had issues but I thought no big deal, when I turn the switch nothing would come on about 2 minutes later it would come on.  About 3 months ago I notice a smell like burning so I would turn it off.  Just last week I went to turn it on since its been a while since I used it, and with in 5 minutes I had to turn it off because the smell of like burning smelled really bad and thank god I was at my desk for all I know the office could of caught on fire.  So today 10/13/20 I decide to turn it on and now it's completely dead.  I called Black & Decker and was told it's not their problem and that it's not under warranty.  Black and Decker I thought was known for great products and service but I have to say that I would not recommend this nor any Black & Decker to anyone if this is how they treat their customers and their product.  It only lasted for 16 months.  My first heater I bought lasted 12 years I guess I should of bought the same brand my first one was but again Blacker & Decker are know for good products BUT NOT NOW!! Thank you for a horrible heater.  I'M SO GLADE I DIDN'T HAVE THIS IN MY HOME GOD ONLY KNOWS WHAT THE OUTCOME COULD OF BEEN WITH MY HOUSE CATCHING ON FIRE!!!!

Title: Good deal when the price is low, use it very local on a fixed electric bill plan
Review Content: This was really a good deal. I purchased that for $15 and it really worth that much. I would double-think if required to pay more though (the price changes with seasons and demands). As far as its operation, it is good for a very small room area (for example under the desk/table or beside your bed). Cannot sustain the warmth in the room for more than a few min after your turn it off. The safety feature works great, but it is good for a place with a fixed electric bill otherwise use of a central heating system will save you energy and money.

Title: Warms YOU up
Review Content: This is the best space heater I’ve ever bought. I run very cold so I use this year round when I need a break from the a/c in the summer and especially in the winter. The only (possible) con to this heater is that it doesn’t heat up an entire room at all. My office’s furnace went out in January and this didn’t do anything for the overall room but it did heat my feet and legs up while being under my desk. I use this on low heat and it works absolutely wonderful for warming up my body.

Title: PERFECT! FIVE STARS!
Review Content: awesome heater! gave it to my sister who sleeps in the attic with barely any heat and it works perfectly. definetly better then expected. keeps her nice and warm even during the below freezing winter nights. it is made with both a control for the speed and power which enables for the most comfortable usage without getting too hot or too cold like those with no controls at all. the best part is its light weight and small design that allows us to move it from room to room without any hassle. thinking of repurchasing another one for my grandparents who would love the extra heat and its easy mobility. thank you for making such a great product!

Title: Possible Fire Hazard
Review Content: I purchased this heater in February from Amazon and it worked great for the last couple of months. It provided great heat, and had a safety feature that would shut the heater off if it got tipped over.Fast forward to June. This last week after being on for about ten minutes, this acrid, burnt smell started coming from the heater. This was followed by a metallic sound coming from inside the heater, then the heat stopped.Of course, I unplugged it right away and e-mailed Black & Decker through my Amazon Order page. I heard back promptly from a person who said that another company handles this heater as one of their "licensed partners". So apparently Black & Decker doesn't handle its own merchandise, at least not in this case.  The person who e-mailed me forwarded my e-mail to this third party company and I hope I hear back.I really liked his little heater, but am afraid to take a chance on it again as I'm afraid it could possibly be a fire hazard. Please be cautious and don't leave this heater unattended.Another Update: I still have not heard back from the company that is licensed by Black & Decker to sell (or make) its heaters. I can't return the heater because it is beyond the return period, so I guess I'm stuck with a heater I won't use because I feel it's unsafe to do so.

Title: Don't Buy This Defective Product!!!
Review Content: I ordered this electric heater on December 25 2023. It finally arrived on January 17.When I plugged the heater into an outlet, the red power indicator light turned on even though I hadn't yet turned it on to the fan, low or high setting. The manual for this product states: "The power indicator light turns on when either FAN, LOW or HIGH setting is selected."This product is clearly defective, wired incorrectly and is likely in violation of UL electrical standards.  I called the manufacturer Black and Decker. When I described the malfunction, the customer support person told me that the heater is defective and directed me to return it to Amazon. I suspect that this is not a one-off problem but more likely a manufacturing defect affecting this model of electric heater. I returned the heater to Amazon but asked for a replacement. The replacement heater had the same defect, so it is a systemic defect.

Title: SAFETY SWITCH TOO CONSCIENTIOUS!  WON'T ALLOW UNIT TO TURN ON - EVEN WITH UNIT UPRIGHT.
Review Content: Well, it does seem to be  VERY SAFE since IT WON'T EVEN TURN ON!  I turned on both dials - the fan and the heat up to High, and I checked the outlet to make sure it was working.  The first heater I received would not turn on at all; even the light wouldn't come on.  The replacement Amazon sent me also would not come on even though the fan was turned on and heat dial was turned up to high.  However, if I press the safety button all the way in, the unit will actually blow out hot air.  Did the factory workers not understand the instructions about how to install the safety switch?  Another reviewer said her husband had to put a piece of cardboard under the safety switch to get hers to work.  Is it safe to do that?

Title: Best Floor Heater I Have Ever Purchased
Review Content: This thing is small, but powerful!  Be careful if you have two running at the same time.  It will knock the power out.  Our kids have rooms toward the front of the house and in the winter it stays a bit chilly and summer very hot.  This has a fan option and a heat option (low & hi).  The low option spits out some serious heat so we haven't needed to use the hi option yet.  For the price, you can't beat it.

Title: Compact & powerful
Review Content: I chose this model because it has dials to set the thermostat & turn the heater on & off. Other models use buttons & don’t clearly indicate the unit is off/ on. It tends to stay on in the early morning hours but lowering the thermostat solves the problem.

Title: Damaged.  Used. & Warning: Cancer and Reproductive Harm
Review Content: I should have read the reviews on this more because I received the same problems others have mentioned.  The box was severely banged up with holes in it.  The heater itself had yellowing and burnish type marks around the heating grill already like it had been used, or it's been sitting in a warehouse for decades aging.I am super concerned with the fact that this product is labeled WARNING: CANCER AND REPRODUCTIVE HARM from California's Proposition 65.  I did not see this presented on the description for selling this on Amazon.  There is no information given on what specific chemical(s) or toxicity you're being exposed to.  But after running it there is a very strong chemical odor and I suspect that's part of it.  Obviously, I'm not going to use it!  Who the f wants to be exposed to that?!It seems to me that this product was recalled or abandoned in the past, stuck in a warehouse for decades and is now trying to be resold.  WTF.

Title: Keeping it toasty

It is exceptionally quiet though. For me, it is a keeper.
